This game takes representation and characters to the next level. Characters have such varying origins and philosophies, you are bound to fall in love with one. You have traumatized war heroes, enby or transgender characters, people who made bad choices and learned from them, Queen fans, and you start to see... the world is so diverse, so beautiful. We can sympathize, we can understand the characters. There are always reasons characters and people act the way they do. It doesn't matter what walk of life you come from, because nothing changes what happens when...

I played a bit more during the Xbox Beta Test. My hours are barely even that here due to the whole refund policy, so...there's that.

Honestly...This game just isn't for me, I guess. Compared to like, Xrd, it's slower, simplified. Plus, I've heard a few horror stories about the matchups and whatnot. Not to mention that a [i]certain controversy[i/] happened. Or the fact that it's still ongoing with little to no neutrality. (It's pretty much both sides atp, don't tell me otherwise.) And it doesn't help that he character in question is almost everywhere at this point. That in itself just kinda...put me off this particular game in general. (I'd go as far to say the character's Guilty Gear's Neco-Arc in probably the worst way possible. But enough of that bs.)

I mean, don't get me wrong, I'm sure the game has its audience. (I mean, obviously. Have ya seen the reception since launch?) But, you gotta admit, the mechanics are a bit dull (albeit better, as of Season 3), and frankly, it feels like it's main appeal is the visuals rather than the game, not so much both at once. (Though, in that regard, I guess that's why the likes of BlazBlue exists.) Still, I guess this, all of this, is inevitably what happens once something enters the mainstream. It starts to get degraded, slowly. More so just eye candy while most of its identity just gets thrown under the bus.

And yeah, I get it, it's accessible and whatnot. But...Is that really worth it...? And maybe these words are just...meaningless.

Truthfully (and hate me if you want), if I do get this back, it's mainly for the cosmetic mods. But, as it stands, this game just doesn't do it for me. I'm sorry. (But sorry isn't enough, is it?)

I expected to be lost against players that are way too strong compared to me since it was the first time I purchased a fighting game, but I was pleasantly surprised when I faced players that were the same level as me, basicly the match making is good.

Edit: Asuka and Happy Chaos are the only dope characters in this game, and they're both zoners. Coming back to give this a negative because i feel it lacks the exciting options and flair of accent core and Xrd, so playing this game after a session of the past games just makes the experience feel bland. The UI is off with no real metal/rock feel, the screenspace feels congested, and the higher emphasis on strike/throw takes away from some of the decision making that was unique to the guilty gears of the past (not to say the past games didnt have some strike/throw to them, just less so).
Also, still no instakills, even though the game moves extremely fast, they were a super fun casual draw to the game with cool animations, so its a shame to see them go in preference of keeping the game more "esports" and "easy to pick up". A lot of these factors build together to making strive feel less substantial, I dont see much reason for coming back to this game anymore past visuals and a few characters (Characters new to strive, typically, because they feel less restricted from a game design standpoint). The other games simply have more style, interactions, variety, and freedom to them.

I don't know what you expect.  It's another fighting game.  Another game where people spam the same input over and over.  Another game with trash hitboxes where you get hit despite being clearly out of range.  And also, confusingly, this game won't let you bring up the menu mid match.  

And, most of these problems aren't just beholden to Strive.  This has been an issue with fighting games in general for the past several years.  Heck, I don't think it's ever NOT been an issue, now that I think about it.  So if you're hard into fighting games, maybe you'll like it.  But if you're an average joe that's only picking this up because your buddy has it?  Don't do it.  Just don't get into fighting games in general.

Reject modern gaming, embrace the FGC.

And Guilty gear, mainly Guilty gear, they're all good.

hot men, hot netplay, hot mechanics, really hot music, really hot graphics, hot combos, hot difficulty, hot lore, hot character design, hot community, hot player count, balance and the ranking system are the only thing that isn't 10/10 or more, but they definitely aren't deal breakers

You can also get Guilty Gear Xrd Rev 2 for really cheap on sale, which is super good too since it has unique mechanics like instant kills, Sol Dragon Install, and some weird ass characters like old Bedman, Slayer, and old Ky. GGST traded these for a more straightforward approach to fighting games, and while I prefer GGST, there is certainly a more casual and silly appeal to the older game (although it can be competitive too)
Guilty Gear XX Accent Core +R is another GG game, but I found it to be a little too competitive-feeling and confusing. The graphics and music also felt much less appealing. It's super cheap on sale as well, though, so it is certainly an option. Whatever you do, I really recommend you don't get the original Guilty Gear, since it's basically a joke game

[i](I have not really played the game that much past Patch 1.29, please keep that in mind. Your experience may be different than mine)[/i]

I have over 600 hours in the game. I've played in offline tournaments for the game with friends and at major events as well. The characters I played the most are Nagoriyuki, Sol, Anji, Axl, and Faust. My highest elo rating was around 1750 from ratingupdate.info, which places me near the top 2%. I could usually beat the average Celestial player but would rarely beat the best / professional players. At the time of my purchase, this was the only fighting game I've played. I started by using an X-Box 360 controller briefly, then a PS4 controller for the majority, my keyboard briefly, and then finally a Hitbox.

I really can’t describe what it is I don’t like about this game anymore, but I’ll do my best. My taste for fighting games in general has definitely changed over time, but so has this game. It’s hard to tell which between the two is shifting my perception the most, but it’s impossible to separate them. As such this review is probably a lot more subjective than what I’d like.

I think the skill required to be a strong player in this game has changed over its release. It’s not that I find it less skillful, it’s more that it’s just different than what I think is impressive. Though to be honest, I feel it has become less skillful overall. I don’t get that impressed seeing a strong GG:ST player anymore. Obviously they’re a lot better than me, but I just don’t think this game at a high level is that interesting or exciting anymore. I don’t see those big, flashy, risky outplay moments happen as often. The power level in this game has gotten too high and it restricts a lot of decision making. Every character now just feels so repetitive and predictable. A majority of the roster is just such a poor time to play against.

I used to watch all the major events for this game, but now whenever I do, I just feel so jaded and annoyed. I’m usually disappointed with the win. There’s always parts of competitive games that I find frustrating, but in this game they’ve been easy enough to overcome or ignore. You must understand that I have over 600 hours in this game and it’s the first fighting game I’ve played. Obviously, I’ve encountered a lot of challenges and hurdles learning this game, but I’ve faced the same things everyone else has in this game. My complaints aren’t about the challenge. These frustrating aspects were never a problem before, but now they are.

I don’t enjoy my time with this game anymore. I strongly dislike it. However, my time spent with it was incredible and it was truly some of the best moments I’ve had playing video games. Unfortunately, I can't recommend it anymore. I don't think I'd have the same positive experience I did if I were to pick the game up now for the first time. The fighting game I play the most now is Street Fighter 6 and while I think it’s a considerably better game, it doesn’t have the luxury of being my first experience with fighting games. As such, Guilty Gear: Strive will always be one of my favorite games ever, even if I don’t enjoy it anymore.

Sorry to say I can’t recommend it.

Was great until season 2 with mediocre character releases and long periods of silence, come season 3 still with mediocre character releases + new mechanics in the game now that throws 'guilty gear simplified' out the window; currently the biggest anime fighter with 2nd best netcode behind SF6, it is still a great game but many people have moved onto SF6 or tekken 8 or just better games out there. Arc has also been doing smaller adjustments infrequently, the game is nearing its end of life span.

Storymode cutscenes were terrible as there were strange pauses between the lines delivered, audio volume was different among characters, some definitely more louder than others; Characters seize all movement during cutscenes and freeze...movements are stiff as heck, resulting in a very unnatural/uncanny cutscene. I don't know how the animators got an OK sign with this level of quality tbh (any other game, the characters have little movements even when they don't speak).
Arcsys shows they are not on par with this kind of storytelling with other major companies out there which is a shame.

If you are getting into this game in 2024, buy the basegame, but don't buy the season pass UNLESS you are sure.

Elphelt is busted. Yeah make fun of me in the comments you simp. "Just use your anti-air when she restarts her rekka" Yeah that doesn't work cause after you hit them they can just use neutral slash and go back into it (For Happy Chaos at least you don't have the frames for any follow up. I'm not giving up my boy over one move). Cherry on top being that she has a zero frame, invincibility granting overdrive (can't even Romanian Cancel to block it). Even if you removed that Elphelt is still just a massive fuck you to new players. You could take a 4F sever and every other player is an Elphelt that spams the rekka. While more experienced players see this as a nuisance most new players don't know how to counter it. Maybe remove the ability to go back into it and just tweak her moves for a more competitive setting and this could be a good character. Right now however she sucks in competitive but destroys low floors. Also I've had a multitude of times when the game thought my roman cancel button was dust. No I did not fat finger, it does this in practice mode as well and I can see the lack of a dust input. Also some attacks hit high and low apparently so neither guard works??? 632146 is neutral (I have tension) and I didn't input any attack. Don't get me wrong I love this game but it really pisses me off when I input something and the game does something completely different. I also don't like how this game picks favorites (I miss point blank grabs while other people grab me from kick distance). On top of the gatling system being completely fucked, sometimes a move gatles into another sometimes it doesn't. Zero consistency on what moves can go into what and sometimes the game straight up discards inputs (Also steady aim broken, curse + steady aim means instant lock on but sometimes it misses anyway). When it works I shoot up to floors 8-10 when it doesn't I'm back down to floors 5-7.

As someone who likes fighting games but only really ever played smash ultimate, I was worried about complex inputs, technical combos, unending move lists etc.
On the surface, GGS looked to me like any other fighting game, with complex inputs and combos, in other words, something I would struggle to pick up and enjoy.
But really it only took me a few hours of doing the tutorial and practicing basic mechanics before i could start enjoying myself, first against bots, then against my friends.

The ceiling is still very high for me but it didn't take long for me to enjoy myself, and to feel like i had some decent understanding of the basics of the game.

I would totally recommend it, even for new fighting game players. It'll take a while to start really having fun with it, but that's true of most PvP games.

At 20$ on sale, it's definitely worth it.

2/2/24 Update. At 350 hours I can honestly say this is the fighting game I compare all others to. It unfortunately began to have server issues and rampant problems with "hackerman" during and after the various crossplay patches which is unfortunate. They tried to make the game better and somehow hurt it. Other than that the future is bright for this game I love it. However Dizzy has yet to be added to the game and that pains me.

11/28/22 Update. I now have 160 hours in on PC alone and another fat stack in on psn. Dizzy still isn't in the game (congrats to all the Sin fans btw) BUT I am having even more fun now! Finding weird interactions in the heat of a match then going back to the lab to replicate them never gets old. The soundtrack is still full of absolute banger after banger. I find myself no longer just floating between characters and instead I now have a main and a secondary (who will be my main eventually). They could fix some of the matchmaking issues and allow us to fish for 50 or 100 at a time though. But generally speaking I love this game and the majority of the community. If you are on the fence just come on over. There is something here for the casuals and the strivers looking to get better.

10/2/22 Update. I now have about 160 hours in between psn and pc. Went to my first tournament yesterday and placed 9th with a 4-2. Dizzy still isn't in the game and I float between multiple characters. No game has brought me as much joy as I've found in Strive. Win or lose as long as I'm not playing a random using that scuffed "Ethernet" cable hooked up to their local smoke shop I'm having fun.

Still no Dizzy but I can be a moe demon with yo-yo's I'd sell my soul to. Yeah I bought the dlc on PSN too what about it?

If this game were purely a rock/metal album, that album would be a 10/10. I have been listening to it for 2.5 years now and it continues to rock just as hard as when it released. If you don't pick the game up, do yourself a favor and give the OST and DLC songs a listen because odds are you will vibe with a song. 
As for the game, this was the first fighting game I could really get into. The movement feels great and fluid. The characters all have unique identities and designs. It is fun to mash, but also extremely satisfying set goals for yourself and achieve them. Strongly recommend.

It's a rlly good fighting game!
If u look at the earlier game's , yes this one was way simplified but it's not exatcly a bad thing.Alot new player's can enjoy it , as average combo's are around 4 hit's long , so u don't have to spend half of ur day labbing just to play. U can ofc make longer combo's by the use of mechanics or trapping someone in the corner.
Speaking of unique mechanic's , u have "Dust" (which let's u launch opponent in the air and do massive dmg combo's to them) , reflect shield , wild assault and roman cancel (let's u slow down time , so u can get away from being hit or extend ur combo!).
Artstyle is SO BEAUTIFUL , daisuke has a rlly original artstyle , u can especially see it in the older art.Which rlly works with characters who are very unique aswell and had allot passion , love put into them! It does have one downsite , which is they look super unconnected during cutscene's. Music is also super good! , I listen to allot of the track's from the game cuz they are just so energetic and metal!
In general I have rlly fun time with the game and despite it's few downsite's I think it's rlly worth a try ,even if ur experienced with fg's. Everything about this game is energetic and fun. I even started labbing combo's cuz of it and Im ready to try little harder games in the future. Thank you Daisuke for this game!

In the realm where sparks ignite the night,
A tale unfolds, fierce and bright.
Guilty Gear Strive, a love untold,
A symphony of passion, a story to behold.

Within the pixels, fighters dance,
Each move a verse, a sweet romance.
Sol and Ky, like stars aligned,
In battles fierce, their destinies entwined.

Arcane forces, a tempest's embrace,
In the heat of battle, love finds its place.
May the echoes of our clashes resound,
As we navigate this battleground.

Ramlethal's grace, like petals in the breeze,
A beauty unmatched, bringing foes to their knees.
In every swing, in every slash,
A love story written in each thunderous clash.

Faust, with his scalpel, mends and heals,
A quirky love, where laughter peals.
In the strangest places, connections thrive,
A testament to love that can survive.

Anji and I-No, melodies in the air,
In the chaos of battle, a love affair.
The strings of fate, they pluck and play,
A harmonious union that won't fade away.

May our battles be fierce, our hearts aflame,
In Guilty Gear Strive, where love's the aim.
Through combos and clashes, side by side,
Our love story in pixels, forever will abide.

The TL;DR
No you shouldn't buy it. 
You're too late, the game is managed horribly, low population(with crossplay), and a bad online systems of sunken cost fallacy nonsense. Which the low population exasperates HEAVILY imagine one instance 32/32 and the other instance is 2/32. WOW WHAT A GREAT SYSTEM. (A general pool system like any other fighting game does would resolve this and brings variety)

Also when it Fatal Errors which UE Games do randomly, it will make your PC unusable until the game finally closes after like 3 minutes. Garbage.


Most of the cast is boring to play and play against. Bridget was brought in to bait and pander non fighting game players to buy the game oogle him then never play again. Easy sales! (This is a insanely objective of a statement in case you have zero friends and acquaintances to garner this data, Testament had no where near the pandering power Bridget did and it shows) 
And the money is all it's about obviously, to the point they delay a CRITICAL network patch to fix the online and wait to push it with the new paid for character. What a hilarious joke. Are they that broke they can't pay for certification of a patch for consoles?
The game is unplayable most of the time, magically you'll get matches, then suddenly you'll be soft-locked from the lobby and have to restart the game to get matches again.

The balance is boring, there's characters that are designed around having the most unfun interactions possible of pure guessing diceroll garbage which the rollback frames shaving off startup of moves certainly doesn't help identifying any of that nonsense. 
There's characters that Arcsys RED have no idea what the hell to do with. They can't seem to figure out how to balance Nago and Ram. They just made Nago take more damage when the player using him is being an idiot (doesn't help in actual proper matches) and due to this character and how they work, the general strategy of what to do against Nago? Don't do anything is the best thing you can do, very engaging! His win condition is existing! And Ram is just an example of balancing off the worst player's. They have no idea how awful it is to play against Ram, they just see bad rams lose and buff her. She used to be a god in the corners, and slightly below average mid screen. NOW she's a god at all parts of the screen.

And the general characters like Happy Chaos, who even enjoys playing against that character? A complete failure of a character slot.
Bedman is plagued by horrible design of just moves that get covered by horribly flashy effects and a useless character in the FOREGROUND walking infront of him and you, constantly just getting in the way visually. You can get a mod to remove the character but that doesn't solve the console players being plagued by it, does it?

There's this whole useless ranking system that is just extremely exploitable and completely binary in how it works. It doesn't account for anything other than "did you win? did you lose" It doesn't care about the player you played against or anything about them.
This is where everyone plays on Floor 10, the highest floor you can pick as "deranking" doesn't mean anything. But oh man what about Floor 11? That horribly useless vanity floor that requires the most absurd requirement I've seen in a fighting game.
You have to 5-1 someone in celestial floor to become a "VIP" which basically means you're locked to it and floor 10.
So I'll laymans what this means. You have to basically beat someone worse than you. Not evenly matched, not better. WORSE than you. To get VIP. What kind of prestigious value does that even have? Anytime you see a VIP RCode you can infer simply "oh he bodied someone who couldn't fight back". Cause that's how you get in. There's no "I won the set I get in" You have to obliterate someone in a set. AND THEN win a set like normal.

VIP should just be 2-1/4-2 requirement. Not 5-1. What the hell is this nonsense? Did they design the floor visually first and think "wow 5 stars sure looks pretty, lets do something with that!" It resets every month anyway so what's the point of trying to get into it if you'll randomly get tossed out? They removed being locked to Floor 10 so now you can just randomly go (AS A PREVIOUS CELESTIAL PLAYER) down to floor 8 arbitrarily trying to populate lower floors cause everyone sits at floor 10 but this has the negative problem of players just harassing newer players. 
As well as just being annoying as anytime you go to Floor 10 (where you belong) and got an unlucky streak against a Nago or something and have floor 8 or 9 as your lowest, it will constantly ask "oh the floor 10 people so scary". Like bro I've been in Celestial, I've beaten floor 10, why are you taking an extra button press now arbitrarily.

It takes them a year just to fix fundamental technical problems with their game(which there's still problems that are known). What confidence you have of them improving anything with the game itself?

There's just no hope for this game, they'll just make it worse, their idea of better defense mechanics is to have yet another spending of resources this time of your burst gauge in this next upcoming update. Wowee can't wait for that to basically do nothing like YRC. Inbred designers.
Can't even fix the FD bug, your bandaid patch was a FD button that most people won't be able to fit on their stick.

For me, fighting games have always been a struggle. Whether it's picking the wrong game (I started with Accent Core +R and then Melty Blood AACC, both of which are extremely difficult games with very good player bases), whether it was just the unfamiliarity with basic system concepts (holding back to block instead of just pressing a button, up also being jump), I never got into it.

Then, one day I saw that Strive was on sale for 50% off. I thought, hey, I got a big paycheck recently, why not try it out? Even at its worst the OST goes hard and I've only heard like a third of it.
I never looked back since then.

At its core, Strive is a game you can UNDERSTAND. People might say it's an easy fighting game or that it's for babies, and they might be right to some extent but nothing changes the fact that anyone can pick up Strive, fuck around in the tutorial for like 2 hours and UNDERSTAND the game mechanics. Of course, all of this didn't make me good; I'm still hovering between floor 7 and 9 these days, but nothing can take away just how much enjoyment Strive has provided for me over the last couple months.

If you're thinking of trying a fighting game and you're willing to spend some money on it, buy Strive when it's on sale. You will not be disappointed.

Despite my hours, my love of the designs of the game, and will play more when DLC comes out, this is probably the worst fighting game to ever learn from, even for beginners. I recommend just playing with friends. I lost a lot of patience's with ArcSystem and the neglect of letting rampant issues involving online becoming progressively worse and letting characters getting way too powerful overtime and not keeping things in check. What happened from launch to now?
Compared to Xrd, they stripped the flavor and removed a lot of the fun.
Whenever you fight anyone, it doesn't feel like you're learning because a tiny mistake and you lose 70% of your health and it's practically game-over from there no matter the skill level. Especially the overly-rewarded emphasis of over-powered offense and don't reward you for defense and playing smart.
It's a real shame that this was my first ever fighting game that I consistently played and the foundations of this game being exposed of simplifying it too much and the power creep with the DLC and general balance.

Guilty Gear Strive; the result of corporate greed, the destruction of profound art, and the beginning of the end of Arc System Works.

After playing this game endlessly on PS4, rebuying it for PC to then eventually play after coming back from a considerable break, and learning of both the history of Guilty Gear and the new path paved by Guilty Gear Strive, I have come to the conclusion that this is not the masterpiece it once seemed to be. In fact, it's the complete opposite; it's a cancer, the beginning phase for the end of the humble, passionate Arc Systems of olden times.

Although I first thought this was nothing to worry about, the further I grow in maturity the further I began to realize the terrible truth. It only got more terrible, and now I've reached the end of my GGST phase, and it unfortunately resulted in this bad review.


= Neutered and Unhealthy Gameplay =
Although pretty fantastic for newer players, the gameplay has quickly devolved into Flow Charting due to lack of depth, and the Rank Tower doesn't help at all. The intention behind the new gameplay was to allow players to learn "without practice", which sounds amazing at first, but then you realize the result: literally zero depth.

Autopilot is rampant in the game as a lot of interactions become optimized very quickly, and since almost every decent player is in Celestial, all those who are slightly below average are facing almost the exact playstyles over and over again. All of the creativity is locked behind a pretty door, so you're fighting flowchart after flowchart below Celestial, which results in you using the same 3 counters against everyone, which eventually turns you into a flowchart as well. It just got boring.

Open Park was better since you could fight anyone, but even then the game got stale. The top of this game is reached fast, which kills long-term enjoyment quickly. Wish the game had more substance, which it continues to receive, but never quite perfects the game. I loved the gameplay until the honeymoon period ended. Now? It's a repetitive bore.


= Bridget, Retcons, and Crappy GGST Story =
Okay, we're gonna get controversial here, so I'll start with something easy: the finale of Guilty Gear. Simply put, it was super underwhelming. Story mode looks shit, which you get used to, but the fact the game sells it like it's some cinematic wonder is just so dishonest. Remember the dishonesty because that comes back later. GGST could have had something amazing with the story mode, but all of the budget went into the game, which is nice for gaming, but that's still a massive L for story mode. The fact this is the FINALE is so shocking; felt like the middle of an anime, not the end.

Now, let's get to the controversy: the horror of modern Bridget.
Holy crap this character was destroyed. Such a lob, not because trans, but because that's all he is now: trans. The fact people like this character shows just how empty the whole movement has become, and that needs to be said even if people think it's transphobic. I'll get flak for this, but I'd rather it be me and not a weaker soul.

There's a great video by someone named Dimitri Monroe regarding modern Bridget. If you want a good idea on why "she" sucks, watch him. Long story short, like Testament, Bridget is trans because... money I guess. People hated Bridget when he was a trap, but now that he is trans, everyone loves him. Why? Idk, cause trans! Yippee!

The OG story was that Bridget left the village in hopes of returning one day and revealing the truth that he was a dude, but that wasn't gonna work by itself so he thought treasures would make it better. Story never really wrapped up beyond that, but GGST was gonna be the finale, so maybe Bridget would finally get to be the boy he was denied from being? That would be beautiful, right?

No, he's trans now.

So, the new story is that, Bridget, who was forced into being a girl or else HE WOULD DIE, went off on a journey to hopefully return treasure to his mean village and be accepted for who he really was, but while he was out, he just gave up and accepted being a girl. So, once she returns, the village welcomes her and the money and doesn't change. The end!

????? 
What??????

Just terrible direction for the character, and it definitely was only done for publicity, and sadly, it worked. Everyone loves Bridget cause trans and that's it. No character, no moving backstory, no resolution that everyone looked for; just a retcon and a middle finger. GGST devs were going back and forth about the canon behind Bridget being a girl or a boy, and, after a failed attempt to gaslight the audience into believing Bridget was trans all along (yes, they really said that), they just admitted it was a retcon and accepted the reality of character assassination. Very disappointing to then learn that everyone loved the retcon, which is just awful. So, so awful.

They don't love Bridget, no, they love what they want to be Bridget. They are just like the mean village; forcing a boy to be a girl, lest they be abandoned otherwise. Disgusting, immoral, and horrific.


= Crappy Initial Content and AWFUL Prices =
I've already written a lot, so I'll make this quick. The launch character and map roster were bad, but when Red Team got some content out, they put it behind a paywall. A large one too. This had been an issue with Fighting Games forever now, the only okay exceptions being Tekken 7 and SSBU since they both had insane rosters on launch, which really made the DLC roster not required for a good roster. That's not the case with DDFZ, GBFV, BBTAG, and now GGST. All of those games started small and made the acceptable content required to be bought with a hefty price. Terrible, greedy, and anti-consumer.

Sadly, most of the gaming sphere has become unbelievably expensive with negligible reward. If they don't have stupidly expensive DLC, they're built on lies and overhype so gamers can buy a $60 dollar piece of garbage. CoD, OW2, Starfield; almost everything nowadays is guilty to a degree, including this Gear... who is Guilty... and Striving...

Too much money, not worth the buy. The pitiful map roster makes the map DLC feel required, and to top it all off, 10+ extra colors for all characters are locked behind a paywall. Xrd had like 20 free colors per character alongside secret colors, while GGST only has 5. Impressive... if you were 3 years old and this was your first original video game. For an entire company dedicated to fighting games? Yeah, that sucks. The fact they actually did do some work but locked it behind considerable paywalls reveals that it's all greed.

Oh, and speaking of greed...


= Why it all happened... LIES and GREED =
Every single one of these problems all come from the exact same origin; the wish for GGST to reach a wider audience. Why? Because money! Of course it is, because humble development is dead. Look everywhere in the gaming market; it's all greed, lies, and all for money. Passion is dead, it's been dead for a decade now.

Make the game easier so more people can play, which equals more money. Retcon characters and make them pure progressive pandering so more people will buy them, which equals more money. Make a terrible story mode and sell it as an amazing cinematic masterpiece so people will buy the game just for that, which equals more money. Oh, and to top it all off, make everything super expensive! Why? To make more money! Money, money, money, money, money!!!

That's all GGST is: a money machine. Whether or not I loved this game, it's clear what the purpose for GGST is, and I'll do my deed to make sure this doesn't get any more money than it already has. I've dumped 150+ already, wish I didn't. What I once considered a hopeful future for fighting games has now shown itself as the dark void that will turn fighting games into the cash cows the rest of the gaming market has become. Sad, but that's reality.

meter system. tension only has use in 50% (was 25% in previous titles), meter gain for attackers usually bigger than defender (not if the defender has significantly bigger HP, but that's another can of worms...), and with RC that basically eliminates risk of a failed attack and how some characters can explode risc gauge (cough, cough ...nago... cough ...) - we have a rather disbalansed and more "party game" experience, where some chars are loved by game systems (nago, HC, leo..) and some are forced to work against the game itself (pot, anji, milla...)

sometimes you feel like playing on 9f rollback but game telling that its only 1-2f (you can literally see one thing but hear other, not good at all), UI isnt greatest also, too many popup menus are very confusing to use (you need to open like 5-6 menus to get to follows or the like)

tutorials are very strange, on one hand there is a lot of information, but they are also often very restrictive in how you can tackle the presented situation (for example - when you being taught what to do against Briget cgrab, you are unable to attack at all, and able to jump only when move is used in mixup, but in reality you can just mash 5P or 2P on cgrab, so not being able to experiment on the spot to find all possible countermeasures is kinda sadge),they mostly don't let you try mashing or backdash (and those are often pretty good in strive),and that's limits your toolkit and approach options.Would be sweet if after you beat the mission withone option that was presented by tutorial, you can retry mission, but that time can use whatever means possible, instead of going and trying to wrestle with training settings to repeat that situation. so in essence most missions are quite meaningless.

arcsys patching is true to traditions - not touching top chars, shuffle mid chars a bit, buff some mid chars (but in such a way, so they won't become better still), and occasionally breaking some unfortunate random for no reason

in the end - strive is easy to start, stylish, and have a lot of ppl playing, but going deeper is full of flaws on a base level and is completely unbalanced.

honestly a lot of ppl online, probably only reason to play that disappointing mess of a game.

people are such babies in this game. its almost impossible to find a match at high level because a majority of people either dodge the match, or alt f4 once they start losing. and since there isnt a punishment for alt f4-ing people do it all the time. its extremely hard to play the game. the community is also very disgusting. on multiple accounts ive gotten told to off myself and ive gotten harassed on other platforms. ive genuinely had a better time playing almost any other genre of game.
Keeps getting better and better with updates.  I hope it'll get to Xrd Rev 2 levels and beyond, eventually but it's still fun

best fighting game

It's a great fighting, not for beginners, but great for intermediate, I'll recommend you get into DBZ Fighters first so the controls feel natural to you since they use the button lay out and are made by the same company.

My first suggestion is to start of with Sol and Ramlethal first. They're great characters, easy to use, and came during launch. Go straight to Arcade mode for each character to understand their story, it's way better than the actual story mode which you can watch it all on YouTube for free, and literally almost everyone in community recommends you do it this way. Buy the DLC you're completely invested or you want to have more variety, it's up to you. Online is great, but keep in mind, they're going to be people who will kick you ass, they had this game longer than you and I.

If you're old school GG Player, there have been a lot of changes. Some characters got a smaller move list or different move list (May, Faust, and Baiken). Some old and new characters are DLC lock (Sin, Baiken, Johnny, Bridget). Oh Yeah, everyone got a redesign either small or big (May, Faust, Elphelt, Testament, and Bridget). They're brand new characters in the game (Giovanna, Nagoriyuki, and Goldlewis), also That Man is now playable (Asuka-R).

Mods are great, I pretty sure they're one-way viewing. We got a lot of pervs in this community. Also a lot of LGBT supportive Community mod that are great, If don't like seeing that stuff and think it's gross, I get it. I just kindly ask you to leave *rack shotgun*, just not calmly. They're also a lot meme mods, like Ronald Sin, KFC Dickinson, everyone has Drip, that one Testament mod (You know the one, bro only has 6).

Overall I think the game is great, it's visually beautiful, with great voice acting, and has great game play. I highly recommend it.

Coming from the Mortal Kombat franchise, Guilty Gear Strive is fucking awesome. A testament to just how much effort went into making this game great is how they took the time to create an original theme song for each character lyrics and all, and they're all absolute bangers. All of the characters are so unique and creative both in terms of gameplay and design. Learning a new character feels like taking a whole new perspective on the game as a whole, and all of the movesets just feel great and look great. A personal thing that I dislike about the game however is how oversexualized the characters are and how pervy the community is lol, but I'm willing to pay the price cause this game is just awesome, me and my roommates have had great times playing this game up till 4 in the morning. I have officially been converted from Mortal Kombat to Guilty Gear.

With the wrong mindset, you'll go into a fighting game, mash buttons, fail, and leave straight away.

With the right mindset, you'll go into a fighting game, mash buttons, fail, and figure out wtf went wrong.

That's been me with GG:S. I initially didn't get what it was that people were on about when they said it was very beginner friendly, as the AI kicked my ass so hard I landed on the refund page, but realizing that I should actually watch out for what I'm doing wrong has earned me 30+ more hours in the last 2 weeks and moments where I feel euphoric.

It's like a self-growth simulation, where how much you grow can be directly reflected in how you perform in game, and it feels weird, but feels so right when you're on a winning streak and your body's full of adrenaline.

-Visuals so good it causes me to lose online matches due to my brain turning into a vegetable in the presence of these fantastic animations.

-Amazingly rewarding gameplay, love that the community can create their own unique combos and upload them, fun character archetypes to learn, counter system thing gives so much oomph to hits.

-Only fighting game I've enjoyed playing online since I'm in South Africa my ping is horrid, god bless Rollback net code. Matchmaking could be better for sure though from what I've experienced but again, third world country infrastructure here. 

Madly in love with this gem of a game. Grab it if you like hitting buttons and seeing really cool shit happen on screen.

If you want an actual epic singleplayer fighting game experience: Find a way to play Soul Calibur II and III. If you want an actual great PVP experience: Go play Tekken 7 or wait for(as of writing this review)upcoming Tekken 8, SF VI(if you can get over Crapcoms monetization and hope that you won't have online issues), GBFV Rising or give Blazblue CF a chance, although that is a "Discord fighter".

This game is an overrated pile of rubbish. This was my first GG game(not my first FG)and I got swept up to the hype train and I regret buying it. I played constantly from the release and I permanently flushed this game when Happy Chaos came out. This review is mostly from the beginning of the game to that point and idc if they have fixed some things, I've already had enough. Here are my reasons for not recommending this game:

- The online is a f*cking shit - show. The battle stations never worked properly since the beginning of the game. We all remember the connecting to the main menu and checking R - Code - shenanigans? Constant disconnects, laggy matches, 4K Counterhit slowdown bug, some stages run like @ss, hackers harassing streamers and many more other technical problems. Atleast they gave us a Wi - Fi indicator. The whole ranked tower is terrible and I know many people who have also said that why not just have a normal ranked queue. It's the traditional Arcsys special olympics poorly implemented lobby/battle station blues which they push to too many of their games.

- The gameplay just isn't fun and is way too offence oriented. The whole gameplay flow just feels obnoxious and watered down to a more simplistic degree compared to older GG games to attract more casuals. I don't have a problem with a long running fighting game series becoming more simplistic but you have to do it well, Strive misses the mark. Everyone does too much damage, rounds are over in an instant, the reversal window is fucked up, some characters just constantly keep attacking and you get a small to moderate punish if you hit them back while if you guess wrong you lose 70% of your life. The corner carry is absurd, worst offenders are Ramlethal and Nago. The fighting games I enjoy like Tekken, Soul Calibur, GBFV Rising and SF VI overall feel much more rewarding for mounting a good defence, this game is just braindead attacking. The whole corner wall break concept is just a deception for making players feel like they got out of the corner for a 2nd chance. In reality the positive bonus what the opponent gets is almost or just as bad as you being in the corner.  For those who care about SP content it's non - existent. Basic Bitch Arcade and a long story movie with zero gameplay.

- The balance is all over the place. This has to be one of the most unbalanced modern fighters I have played. Since the very beginning Sol had his notorious F.S and "The Kick", then we had the Nago deletes your lifebar in the corner - reign, Ramlethal is still an 10 IQ overtuned character and finally we got one of the most cancerous characters ever made in a fighting game: Happy Chaos. I rather watch paint dry on the wall than play against him. Every "meta" just felt like a tiresome chore to play. As for some weaker characters: They waited for a century to buff characters that needed those buffs or never tweaked anything. After twiddling their thumbs each season for too long they eventually nerfed or tweaked Sol, Nago and Happy Chaos, but I already lost my respect towards the games balance team who clearly don't know what they are doing. They don't know how to make the game balanced and fun for all skill levels which is 100% possible to do.

- Everyone circlejerks the OST like it's the best thing ever. It's not. There is 3 good songs(RotS, DoP and Hellfire)while the rest are either mid(e.g Zato, Johnny)or grabage(e.g Baiken(her older themes are 100x better), Giovanna, Elphelt, Ram). If you want good FG OST go listen to Soul Calibur, Blazblue, older Tekken, SF, KoF or older GG(When I heard X2 tracks after Strive music, Strive got absolutely smoked).

- I read the lore a lot, because this was my 1st GG game and the amount of pandering and virtue signaling to a certain obnoxious, unhinged and spastic group of people is borderline comical. Maybe it's partially because Daisuke got married and started to partake in the school of soy? Retconning Bridgets and Testaments whole backstories, making certain female designs more "family - friendly"(i'm surprised Baiken didn't get censored)while Anji and Johnny are build - up like Adonises. They did all that but then they censored all mentions of certain areas from the in - game story glossary, you know what I'm talking about. Seems hypocritical to me. Look, I want my males handsome and cool and they can show skin as much as they want, but you can't tell me there is a double - standard and it just keeps getting worse and worse as a whole in video games. All these things for modern audiences who most likely won't even play the fucking game.

- And to comment on some of the new and re - desings overall: so much of them are lamer than the previous GG games. I like anime aesthetics myself, but I know that many GG fans didn't like the Xrd designs because they were too anime and I can respect that. I think the X2 and Xrd aesthetics are both miles better than Strive's. Ky Kiske, May and Elphelt went all from having unique fantasy clothes to wearing boring and uninspiring everyday clothing. Giovanna, a newcomer, has the same issue. Testament on the other hand had a more darker, simplistic look and now he looks like some over the top fashion model that tries to have more "realistic" clothing but just ends up looking ridiculous. No wonder the old characters that didn't get changed were the most well received, because why fix something that is already 10/10? If you want to re - design old characters atleast do it properly like for example Tekken.

Amazing music, cool design's and an interesting world. God awful game, if you haven't played it or it's predecessors. This game is in no way designed for new players, the tutorials will easily eat up 5 hours+ of your time, and that time is doing bear bones do X combo, do Y combo during Z scenario. There is no campaign to play and learn the game play through and finally there is around 100-500 people playing it online which means you will have to know someone else to play someone new or get your ass beat as the skill ceiling is so high that you have no chance of doing anything. 

If you like the game series I am sure you will like it, but if you are looking at reviews considering to buy it, don't. Any other fighting game is better to play if you are new or learning.

Visually and musically the guilty gear franchise has always been top notch. Mechanically, for me, it has always been missing. It sits somewhere between street fighter and an anime fighter without being either. It feels slower and less fluid than any anime fighter while not as mechanically sound as street fighter. It just sits humbly betwixt. If this is fine for you than it's an impeccable game. But if you're looking for that streamlined combo flashiness of a Blazblue, than this ain't it chef. Also the base roster is purposefully gimped for fans of the series so you're forced to buy dlc if you want any fan favorites which feels kind of rude.

||
Here's the updated review.
The negative review stays but for absolutely different reasons.
This game started off pretty popular because it was actually very easy to pick up and play for an anime airdasher, featured (and still does) some simplified mechanics like gatlings are very short in this game or there is no airteching and there are only two kinds of knockdowns, soft knockdown and hard knockdown.
In the early days the lack of airteching was the only real gripe I had with this game because it essentially rewards players who can't do their combos since even after a dropped combo (a massive failure most of the time) leads to your opponent landing directly in front of you and giving you a so called meaty. This leads to no repercussions for people that play badly (very prominent in this game).

Nowadays I have only problems with this game
First of all balancing is out of whack and I don't mean it in a way that "some characters are weaker and some are worse" because every fighting game is like that, without exception.
The problem with this game is that the devs clearly have favorites that usually the community calls for nerfs so devs will usually try to address these characters and in a few months they will "adjust" these characters.
What that usually meant is they would write an entire article in the patch notes how they changed a move people had a problem with and then "to compensate" they would buff some other aspects of their kit.

This on paper makes sense, nobody likes their character to be nerfed, but what had happened in reality, usually the move that was nerfed, what happened to it for example: the hitbox usually was reduced by one pixel or the move was slowed down by one total frame and then the same move would get 5 different buffs and the rest of the characters' kit would get a lot of buffs too.
This made a lot of other characters play catch up and pretty much the entire cast with few exceptions kept getting only buffs (and what I mean by that, the favorites kept getting buffed, or as said earlier if the character wasn't liked by the community they got one nerf and 10 buffs to compensate, while some characters that weren't devs' favorites were just kept in the dust) and playing against any and every character feels like a chore and is very unfun.
This is what you would call a "kusoge" lit. "shit game" and to elaborate, almost all characters have such an insane power level they feel nothing like they did in patch 1.0 and not in a good way, they're all a knowledge check or have a way to shut you down completely meaning you can't really do anything once you lost neutral, or some characters being so oppressive, you pretty much lose as soon as you pressed "start" against them, unless you play equally as a top tier character.

I'm not sure if the server issue was addressed or simply the hacker attacks stopped, the game is playable now, albeit significantly less people to play with.
If you have a friend or two to play with, friendlies are still really fun to mess around in, but playing ladder it feels like taking "fighting game" to it's literal sense because it feels less like fighting another person and more like quite literally fighting the game.


If you want an alternative to a fun anime airdasher with rollback here is some equally or more kusoge games but they're either cheaper or more fun (or both), especially with friends:
[b]Blazblue Central Fiction[/b]

[b]Guilty Gear Xrd[/b] or [b]+R[/b] (all three are also from Arc System works)

[b]Melty Blood Actress Again Current Code[/b] or [b]Melty Blood Type Lumina[/b]

[b]Under Night In Birth II Sys:Celes[/b] as of writing this review is coming out soon (the three mentioned here are from France Pan and the movement is very satisfying in these games, Current Code is a kusoge through and through but is fun in friendlies (there is a rollback version of MBAACC outside of steam), Type Lumina is actually fairly easily approachable)

Not a lot of people play these games but tbf that can also be said about Strive nowadays as well.

I first started getting into trad fighters with SFV after being a Smash player for most of my life, but I think Strive is what truly cemented my love for the genre. The gameplay is so punchy, so meaty, so fast, it's like a perfect middle-point between the rigid mechanics of trad fighters and the freeform combos and movement of platform fighters. It was so easy to pick up, but there's so much to learn and get better at. I think it's a perfect first fighting game.

Additionally, this is what got me into Guilty Gear, and Guilty Gear is freakin' AWESOME. The characters, the story, the gameplay...it's easily one of the most underrated game series out there. Learning about the series and watching high-level gameplay videos has become a huge pastime of mine, and, as a game developer myself, I take a lot of influence from the series' approaches to gameplay balancing and character creation.

However, the peak of this already peak game is definitely the music. GGST's soundtrack is quite possibly my favorite OST of all time, which I do not say lightly, and is probably one of my favorite albums period. I'm serious, if there is any game to get into just for the music, it's this one. There isn't a single bad track on the whole album; sure, some are a little uninteresting, but they're intermixed with some of the greatest rock songs I've ever heard, songs written with passion and emotion that tie together this brilliant clusterfuck of a game.

I'd give it a perfect rating, but there are some pretty obvious flaws like annoying top tiers/balance and the dreadful online interface, so it'll have to settle for just nearly perfect.

Never wrote a real review for this game so here I go. Guilty Gear Strive is a wonderful fighting game. The music, visuals, game play. All great, and is actually starting to feel a lot better because of changes made that I really like, such as wild assault and deflect shield which add more decision making with the burst gauge. I wish some things were different like words can not express enough how much I hate air dashing in this game, it feels like your flying through molasses before you get any momentum with a forward air dash and then the back air dash is just pathetic. While that's not my only complaints everything else I guess I don't despise that much. If you are someone new to the genre, I really do recommend! If you just take things slowly and play with the mentality of "I want to improve" You will get better. If you don't care about that you can grab a glue bottle and hit the funny grab move with the giant behemoth of a man that is Potemkin.

Even though i would still recommend this game to someone who has never played another fighting game in their life(and only in this case!), as they will still be able to enjoy the fundamental fun every FG possesses, i cannot in my right mind give it a positive review with these design flaws that ruin the fun:

-Damage is too high. You will die in 2 interactions most of the time. Even when you win, it will feel hollow, as more often than not, Rounds aren't won by outplays and sorta "just happen".....now try to imagine how you will feel on losses lol

-The wall mechanic. The guy who worked to put you in the corner doesn't get to benefit that much from his positioning advantage, as it's hard to not break the wall, making screen control feel less worth. The one who got cornered will still get messed up by the extra damage and positive bonus he's about to deal with. It brings nothing good to both players outside of cool looking stage transitions, just a hassle.

-Small move list for characters. It didn't bother me that much at the start, but you really start to feel a bit limited and bored after playing the same character for a while. 

If more people gave their honest reviews, this game would have nowhere near it's unwarranted 92% approval.

As an ardent fan of the Diablo series, I was overjoyed to embark on the dark and treacherous realm of Diablo 4. With nearly 20 hours of immersive gameplay under my belt, I stand here in awe of the epic journey that awaits any intrepid adventurer who dares to traverse its sinister landscapes. Allow me to share my experience, which has undoubtedly left an indelible mark on my gaming soul.

From the moment I stepped foot into Diablo 4, I was greeted by a breathtaking world meticulously crafted by the visionary minds at Blizzard Entertainment. The attention to detail is second to none, with hauntingly beautiful environments that simultaneously evoke a sense of dread and wonder. Every corner of this world pulsates with life, and the atmospheric graphics draw you in, making it impossible to escape its grasp.

The gameplay mechanics of Diablo 4 are nothing short of addictive. The combat is an exhilarating dance of destruction, whether I was unleashing devastating spells or wielding mighty weapons. The fluidity and responsiveness of the controls heightened my sense of empowerment, enabling me to effortlessly dispatch hordes of foes in a symphony of chaos.

But Diablo 4 is not merely about mindless hack-and-slash action. The intricate web of lore and storytelling weaves its magic throughout the game. Engrossing quests and captivating dialogue breathe life into the rich tapestry of Diablo's universe, introducing memorable characters and gripping narrative arcs that kept me invested and hungry for more.

The character progression system in Diablo 4 is a testament to its depth and replayability. As I honed my skills and unlocked new abilities, I felt a genuine sense of growth and evolution. The freedom to customize my character's playstyle and experiment with various builds added an additional layer of excitement, ensuring that no two playthroughs would ever be the same.

It would be remiss of me not to mention the cooperative multiplayer aspect of Diablo 4, which amplifies the experience to staggering heights. Joining forces with fellow adventurers, battling formidable bosses together, and sharing in the spoils of our conquests created a sense of camaraderie that is truly unparalleled.

In terms of longevity, Diablo 4 offers an expansive endgame that guarantees countless hours of enjoyment. From the challenging dungeons and raids to the endless pursuit of powerful loot, the game continually entices you to push your limits and prove your mettle. With future updates and expansions promised by the developers, the Diablo 4 experience promises to be an enduring odyssey.

In conclusion, Diablo 4 is an absolute masterpiece that has captivated my gaming heart. Its awe-inspiring visuals, addictive gameplay, immersive storytelling, and robust multiplayer elements combine to create a gaming experience that is nothing short of legendary. If you seek an adventure that will leave you spellbound and craving for more, Diablo 4 is an absolute must-have. Prepare yourself, brave adventurer, for a journey that will forever be etched in your gaming memories.

This is a really fun game. The character designs are unique and diverse, with fighters that range from a looming doctor with a bag over his head and a scalpel shaped spear, to an anime girl who summons dolphins, to a witch with an electric guitar. They even got Saul Goodman in on the action. Additionally, there is trans/nb representation here in the form of Bridget & Testament (DLC fighters). I love to see it! 

The music is great too, with each character having their own theme. The gameplay is flashy, and the timings for motion inputs aren't too tight which means that I (a noob at fighting games) can still use them. The graphics often convincingly look like 2D animation, which is something that I love to see. 

There is no real story campaign, instead there is a long story cutscene. I really would have preferred if there was a story focused single-player aspect. Still, this has become my favorite 2D Fighter

[b]Return-to-game addendum[/b]: So I went back to this game after a much-needed several month break, and found it in much the same state I left it in. Horrendous powercreep as the devs try to one-up their previous handiwork with the new line of DLC characters, hideous lobby system that tries(?) to evoke pixel-art charm but looks more like a cheap shovelware 2D platformer, nonsensical bugs that at best prevent you from starting matches for no reason and at worst completely softlock the entire game, lop-sided ranked system that top-loads way too many players in rank 10, it's like I never left. What [i]is[/i] new is that they added a few new universal mechanics and some new moves to characters, but I saw precious little of these in my online matches, so that should give you an idea of how meaningful those additions were. My previous stance on this game remains the same: it's a frustrating, poorly designed (mechanically-speaking) game that manages to worsen over time, but not altogether unpleasant, especially if you have a high tolerance for bullshit. Original review below.

I have a deep love-hate relationship with this game. I love the incredibly diverse cast of characters; I hate how often I see some characters more than others (and I mean [b]way[/b] more than others). I love the way I can connect and play against others from across the world; I hate how the lobby system that you need to use to do this sucks complete ass. I love how some fights can be a brutal, nail-biting, adrenaline-pumping tug-of-war where it's anyone's game; I hate how [i]most[/i] fights are one-sided steamrolls where neither side really enjoys the game. While it's easy to see the vast number of upsides that Guilty Gear Strive has to offer, I cannot recommend this game for several reasons:
[list]
[*] [b]Character balance has been and always will be horribly broken[/b]. Starting with perhaps the most egregious fault of GGS, the character balance. There are characters who are objectively strong in all circumstances with few drawbacks. There are characters that have historically been incredibly weak, regardless of the laundry list of mundane "balance patches" since launch. Those that find themselves in the middle of this dichotomy often are nominally balanced, except for the one attack in their moveset that is [i]wildly[\i] overpowered, meaning any player will spam that attack to great effect at very little cost. Everyone who plays this game knows this, and it shows every time I log into multiplayer and see the lion's share of players pick the same five characters, falling into the same type of playstyle, making online play very predictable and redundant. 
[*] [b]The lobby system is utter rubbish, and nothing has been done about it[/b]. This is another thing that has troubled the game since launch. For all the gorgeous visual style that GGS is famous for, Arc System Works made the baffling decision to implement a lobby system that is barely functional, unintuitive, and horribly ugly to boot. The number of times that I have been randomly kicked back to the title screen (not the main menu, the [b]title screen[/b]), denied a match with another player for no reason, denied the ability to queue up for a match, disconnected while in the middle of a match and kicked back to the title screen, soft-locked myself while trying to queue up for a match, loaded into a match before being disconnected before it could even begin and then immediately kicked back to the title screen, I cannot even begin to fathom. Despite claims of fixes in the multitude of patch notes since launch, the problems persist with no sign of abatement. And just for clarity, it takes a solid minute for me to go from the title screen to playing the game again. [b]EACH. TIME.[/b]
[*] [b]The DLC characters are just ridiculous, what were they thinking[/b]. Earlier I mentioned the abhorrent job ASW did at balancing the base characters in this game, but that is nothing to say about the trainwrecks of balance that are the DLC characters, which practically border on pay-to-win. Each new DLC, with the exception of Goldlewis, has added an objectively better character than most all of the base cast. More range, faster recoveries, higher damage, smaller hurtboxes; these characters lend themselves to a reckless and uninspired playstyle of spamming the same overpowered moves with impunity, knowing they will always have the advantage over anyone who plays any other character. You need only juxtapose Axl Low, a hardcore zoner with limited close-range abilities and okay damage who is available in the base game, and Happy Chaos, a hardcore zoner DLC character who deals mondo damage, has close-range abilities that can knock encroaching opponents back to the other side of the screen, generates tension meter by the truckload even when his attacks are blocked, effortlessly forces opponents to cautiously approach on penalty of losing all their forward progress, has a long-range spammable attack with very little downtime, AND a super that can hit literally anywhere on the screen. The difference is night and day.
[*] [b]If you're not a god at the game, ranked mode is extra depressing[/b]. "Git gud to enjoy the game" is an abysmal approach toward game design, but the geniuses at ASW have gone and done it anyway. For context, the ranked mode is a "tower" comprised of 10 levels, in a way "roughly" sorting everyone by skill level; beat enough people, go up a floor. Then there's a "secret" 11th level where you can "earn" the right to try and win 5 out of 6 games against players already in the floor to actually be able to regularly play there, but that resets each month unless you're so good your avatar goes super saiyan and catches fire (this is only a [i]slight[/i] exaggeration). There is a critical problem with this arrangement. Expecting a 10th floor player, which is already a pretty good skill level all things considered, to win 5 out of 6 games against objectively more-skilled players is ludicrous, because even if one was [i]evenly-matched[/i] against them, they would only win half of their matches on average; that's just basic math. For obvious reasons, no one can enter matchmaking for a floor that is lower than their current rank, but this means that anyone who is in floor 10 but cannot match into floor 11 can [i]only[/i] match in floor 10 and no where else. As a result, the 10th floor is overcrowded with players who likely have the skillset to go toe-to-toe with those on the 11th floor, but because of the obtuse rules toward gaining entry to match with such players, are forced to fight over and over on the 10th floor, often steamrolling those who are trying to earn entry into the 10th floor rank. It's an aggravating environment that does not accurately measure players' skills and frequently fails to generate enjoyable matches against evenly-skilled opponents, which signals a complete and utter failure to implement a ranking system.
[\list]

This is a non-exhaustive list of my gripes with all the horrible design choices in GGS, but it's all the points I feel are relevant for any prospective gamers looking into it. 250+ hours of trying my damnest to love this game, which I genuinely did for a time, have all converged into this depressing and pessimistic review warning all of its perils. And yet for all the complaints I have laid out, there is still a pretty good game buried under it all. Although all the hours I have sunk into it have left me jaded and disappointed, I am clearly in the minority, and even now I will admit the obvious: it's still a fun game. To anyone thinking of buying this game, think twice and please take the points I listed above into consideration, that's all.

It's time to write a review about Strive. The game is a good one for first timers. It's like a simplified version of XRD. Got very decent soundtracks. If it's your first time playing a GG game go for it. If you played XRD before let me tell you something. It's different. At first you'll say "eh, is it really worth it?" Then you will start asking the real questions like, "where is instakill?", "why are there so few special attacks/combos?" and "WHERE IS ELPHELT?". Well, at first, I wasn't a fan of the game. Now? I love it. Returning XRD feels very different now but in a bad way. I love both games. They are both good but I'll keep playing Strive not XRD. The main reason is the playerbase. XRD is basically dead. After the rollback update it is better than before but still not enough. It aged and it shows that. Bought it and now I got no money. Do I regret it? No. Will I survive? Who knows.

I'd love to have a bit more single player content, but it's a more of nice-to-have for me. Lore wise I can't complain though. 
Regarding multiplayer: Netcode is fine and gameplay feels smooth, just the occasional server issues can be annoying. I heard that the ranking system has some issues on the higher levels, but I can't really address that since I'm not at that level yet.

I'm not a big fan of Guilty Gear. I started with XRD a while back and since the single-player for that one was so goofy I thought about going back through the series to learn more but nothing about the gameplay looked significantly different from XRD in an interesting way. This game certainly feels distinct. When I bought it, I didn't really like Strive for anything but it's art direction and soundtrack. The gameplay felt a too easy and I thought the whole "wall-break" mechanic was really shit for a game with burst and RC which gave players plenty of room to escape the corner or even reverse that pressure effectively. Now it's almost exactly the opposite. Out of the original roster the only change I didn't like was Faust but out of the DLC the only redesigns I like more than the original are Jack-O, Bedman, and Testament and I haven't liked a DLC song since Baiken's theme. On the other hand the "drive-rush" lite mechanic they've introduced has made the gameplay feel far more fluid to me. It's still not very difficult to do well in Strive but freestyling combo's is feels way better when you can play fast and loose with the new mechanic. It's not very balanced and you can certainly FEEL when a character is good but that's not always a bad thing. I like the direction it's going and honestly, as long as the gameplay improves I don't care how much they botch the designs. Besides Dizzy, please don't do that to Dizzy. Please.

- The tower ranking is great! I'm new the fighting games and still was able to play with people at similar skill level! You don't just get absolutely destroyed by people! I'd definitely recommend people to play online! 

- Single player wise, there is an arcade mode that you fight 8 rounds with increasing difficulty. There is also a survival mode, VS mode, missions which are basically extended tutorials for fighting games and the game mechanics. Other than that, there's a story mode, which is just a movie, no gameplay.

- There are no "unlocks", you'll have to pay for new characters. You can play to get money for avatar items and room decorations though

TL;DR: Not much single player content, if you don't have friends to play with or don't want to play online, there's not much to it.

It plays well on both my Steam Deck and PC. Arcsys has done a phenomenal job with the art direction, performance, game feel, and music for this game.

Something that still bothers me so much about this game since day one is the online. Matches play great when you actually are able to get into one thanks to rollback netcode, but trying to get a game going can be a major hassle. There are times where I tried connecting with multiple players for a good 15 minutes to get something going before I had to back out all the way to the title screen to login again. Extremely frustrating and can take the wind out of wanting to continue playing.

The gameplay itself is fine and welcoming for newcomers with the colorful cast of characters. I came back recently just to try out Elphelt and she plays fantastic.

My gripe so far is that the game can be wildly unbalanced even with all the new system mechanics like Wild Assault and Deflect. It does make those moments where you can steam roll really fun but the opposite end of it feels pretty bad. I don't have an exact answer on what to do with this but the way how the meta feels is why I stopped playing early Season 2. Because of this wild unbalance, it doesn't make it a fun game to spectate either.

If you're coming in and wanting to learn a fighting game, this is a great game to do so. The game is still actively being played and you're bound to have a good time. If you're a longtime fan, you'll definitely be seeing the holes in this game on higher levels of play.

I'd overall would recommend this game because it is a solid game. Guilty Gear Strive has brought in so many new players to this awesome franchise and I'd love to see it grow even more.

Strive gets so much right, but we're 3 DLC seasons and several patches in and the lobbies STILL do not work. As it stands, I currently get one online match in the lobbies before I am "disconnected from the host". Results are mildly better when I am in a private room with friends, but I always run into some kind of connectivity issue within an hour of gameplay. My friends' experiences are pretty similar; this seems to have nothing to do with system or connection issues, but with server load and functionality. 

Not to mention that right now, dozens of successful streamers currently cannot play this game online because of an exploit of the R-Code system, where malicious entities can freeze another user's game, post messages through their avatar's chat, and cause other problems.

This game is beautiful and so much fun to play when it works, but in an era of incredible new fighting games with good netplay experiences, I am unable to keep making excuses for these developers. These games live and die by their online community, and Strive's is dead in the water. I'd sooner recommend older games in the series that, for some reason, work far better online (ex: Guilty Gear Xrd or Accent Core Plus R)

Yes and no. But at the end of the day if every guilty gear was wiped off the face of the planet the Earth would be a better place. A fan of guilty gear can either be one of the kindest, most chill people you'll ever meet, or a complete piece of shit. The only in between is people who are technically "nice" but they're annoying as fuck. You can find nice and chill people like the good guilty gear fans everywhere both irl and online, but bad guilty gear fans are a special type of insufferable

What's playing the game feel like?

It's like dating the hottest guy in the world. His skin is smooth and silky, he has gorgeous lips and flowing wavy hair, and he has a lovely voice. Unfortunately every time he sees you he beats the shit out of you and calls you slurs. He's into raceplay, likes kids, and threatens to gut you if you ever think of leaving him. He used to act like an angel but the longer you've dated him the more of a bastard he's shown himself to be

I DO NOT recommend this game to people who...

Enjoy playing games with friends, like having fun, like playing more than one video game at a time, like comprehensive game mechanics, or want to continue enjoying life on this planet

I DO recommend this game to people who...

Like being abused, enjoy arguing with other people on the internet, want to become an insufferable human being, or are on the brink of ending it all

If you do end up buying this game stop the moment you get into celestial floor, it exclusively gets worse from there

At the end of the day all the best parts of this game can be experienced without actually playing it
(like most fighting games)

Buy it if you want

Season 3 has introduced numerous changes to make the game more dynamic and allow players to better express their playstyle. Numerous balance changes were done to characters so that many moves are no longer as overloaded as before, increasing the amount of skill needed to use some characters like Chipp and Ramlethal.

Edit: As time goes on however, it becomes apparent that the Season 3 changes also kinda made snowballing even stronger, if pulled off properly (looking at Chipp). Fortunately, this won't be the case for almost any other level, but for celestial and the top ranks, it can be a little much. They should just remove the Burst regen for positive bonus to reduce the capabilities of snowballing.

It's whatever. It's the most mid fighting game ever made, carried entirely by having the best netcode. The lobbies to this day are completely dysfunctional and make you want to stop playing before you even start. The gameplay is fine for a simple low, investment FG. The characters all feel relatively bland/limited compared to older Anime Fighters including previous entries in the series. And it has THE SINGLE WORST character design in modern FGs, Happy Chaos. If you know, you know. At least the soundtrack is fire. The game's biggest strength is that it released in the perfect window where all the great older FGs were starting to reach their end of life, and nothing much was on the immediate horizon. I guess it could be a good gateway to get new FG players into the genre so they can find actual good FGs.

Edit: Never mind, dumb ass Elphelt comes in to save this mid game.

Im dissapointed in the new player experience.
First of all I alwas wanted to get into fighting games. I also understand that those games are especially complex and fast pased. Therefore as a very beginner I started out with the tutorial missions.
Even in the very first tutorial missions I got really frustrated. Let me list a few examples:

- Double Jump
 "evade the attack by Jumping and then use a jump in any direction" - well turns out even while the tutorial specifically list diagonal inputs you can only do a normal double jump. Since the timing to evade the attack is quite precice and at my first two tries I plunged directly into the attack I assumed that I should evade the attack by jumping sideways. I basically did multiple diagonal inputs in the air in it just didnt work. In the end the tutorial text was just wrong and the tutorial only allows for a straight upwards double jump

- General Input Timings
I generally had/have no Idea what certain symbols mean. A curved Arrow from Right to bottom, then straight right was confusing to me. I interpreted as right, down, right. I tried it out and failed over and over. Then I thought maybe its down, right, down instead, since from the symbol I couldn't really tell. Here I just had to input the buttons very fast (I used my d-pad on a controller, its way easier with the analoge stick). This misunderstanding is annoying. And I feel like an idiot trying out what seems to be easy instructions, there is so much guesswork.

- Basic Recommendations
I still do not know If Guilty Gear should be played with a keyboard, Controller (analoge stick) or Controller (D-Pad) and im sure there are people who can play with either of those controls. But for me I was unsure if my misinputs are just natural, a lack of talent, or if im using the "wrong" input device. The control I mentioned previously was easier to execute with an analoge stick, while inputting via analoge stick proofed to be very finicky when I tried to perform air dashes.

- Overall Experience
In my hour of testing I felt like doing an exam. I had no fun and it seemed to that I would need to invest another 5 hours just to get the basics down. Then I would have to memorize several input string and bite my tongue for every misinput in game. I just can't see the light at the end of the tunnel and wish that there is a breadcrumb of fun in the learning path that keeps me going. I refunded the game because im afraid of giving up half way, being frustrated for hours and have spend money for that experience.
