I used to love this game. It has fantastic graphics and music and super fun/addicting gameplay, so I definitely understand it's initial appeal.  I started having problems once I started to even remotely take this game seriously a couple of hundred hours in when I really felt I had mastered the mechanics. I started to notice little things about the game I didn't like; The game is just WAY too simple overall, each character has less than 1/2 the moves they had in Xrd. There are also characters that are just.... Objectively easier to play and therefore better than others (May, Ky, Sol, most of the DLCs) people will try to convince you this is not true but they are coping HARD do not listen. While the mechanics are pretty fun and have a decent amount of depth overall, the characters feel incredibly simple. It's like playing Super Smash Bros. with Street Fighter mechanics.  The game has a diverse roster of characters that are super fun to mess around with at first,  but I find that there's just not enough depth to explore within the movesets besides a set few characters, which is INCREDIBLY disappointing considering this games predecessors are Blazblue Centralfiction (different series, same devs) and Xrd. I understand that a lot of moves may overwhelm new players, but that's the entire point of implementing a simplified moveset that filters out just a few moves to choose from. (Ex: Street Fighter 6 simple controls) Another MASSIVE problem with this game is that it has the WORST ranking system in any fighting game I've ever seen. The floor system is absolute garbage, and if anything prevents you from getting proper matches by giving you the option to pick your "floor" while needlessly gatekeeping the "Celestial" floor off to players that win A CERTAIN AMOUNT OF MATCHES IN A ROW (Basically pure chance unless you want to play the game to the point of actual suicide) This leads to a myriad of problems, the most prevalent of which being that if you lose more than (basically 1) match in a row (which is inevitable because it's a fighting game) you lose your floor/rank! Which makes it virtually impossible to obtain a rank of any kind, leaving people with thousands of hours on the game to just sit around and farm wins off of people that are worse than them. The floor system also lets you pick your own opponents in the worst most tedious way possible, frequently leaving you switching between different online lobbies to even FIND a match. Not to mention the game freezes frequently when waiting for online matches, which is adds extra insult to the massive, life threatening injury that is Guilty Gear Strive online. Previous games (Blazblue and Xrd) had lobby settings for friends, but simplified the matchmaking to just clicking a name on a screen and getting into it. Street Fighter 6 has much better online capabilities and the characters are just as diverse so if you're looking for a serious online experience I'd reccoment that or Centralfiction/Guilty Gear Xrd instead. While SF6 is new, those other two are  a bit dated but probably some of the most fun I've had with this genre. As I said before I really used to enjoy this game and recently I came back to it and tried so, so hard to enjoy it again but I cannot play this game without a deep, insatiable rage taking over me. As much as I want to enjoy this game, I DETEST Guilty Gear Strive with every ounce of my being, but I do think it's a decent game and will play it sometimes. Honestly, I HIGHLY reccomend if you're just getting into fighting games, you'll have MUCH more fun with this than a tryhard ass game like Mortal Kombat or Street Fighter, but if you're looking for like... a decent fighting game experience, I'd reccomend Blazblue, Soulcalibir, Street Fighter 6, Xrd, Mortal Kombat 11 (Haven't played the new one), Marvel vs Capcom, or pretty much any other game that isn't this one, Melty Blood, or Dragon Ball FighterZ.

A really fun 2D fighting game. I really enjoy fighting games but I've never been very good at them. Guilty Gear -Strive- offers a lot of both people like me on a casual level, as well as those who try to take their abilities to the absolute limit at a competitive scene. 

The cast of characters, their design, and the expansive soundtrack are this game's strongest points. I think this series is really unmatched when you consider the roster overall. There is plenty of fighters to pick from for a person to really find their 'vibe', both in terms of their move set and their respective personalities. Overall I think Guilty Gear has the most unique and fun atmosphere about it, and that's saying a lot considering how many fighting titles are out there these days.

Great Fighting Game. Amazing Online surpasses any fighting game I've played. Really enjoy the learning from floor 6 to celestial. Game has a sound track you'll listen to on spottily when you're done. Superb fighting game!

 In low level and mid level play its fun, execution of moves and combos are easy/simple and tense. Floor 6-10 is the most fun.

 In high level play(Celestial), you play neutral and someone converts 1 hit in to a 60% health damage combo. Nago and Sol particularly went from fun match-ups from floor 6-10 to 80% heath bar damage gods.. 

Personally, I think the only way to fix it is to give other characters the ability to get value off their counter hits. I like the fast paced aspect. You really get maybe 3-4 correct guesses to stop/reverse pressure and fights are like popcorn...good luck playing just one. (Edit They have added new moves so struggling characters can convert) 10/10 Fighting game. Updates and balance patches are at the right frequency.

Unique characters, stylish gameplay, and a lot of fun to play. Playing online is usually a smooth experience as well.

Everything you'd want from a fighting game is here. And the characters keep coming!!

This is probably my favorite fighting game. Ever. That is an objective fact, and not just for me. It has cemented the 2D fighter genre as something I will enjoy for the rest of my life. A rocking soundtrack, visual flair and animations that are blast to watch and hear even over 200+ hours logged (+130 more hours on Playstation), and impactful, responsive control that you can feel in you fingertips as you scramble to counter, RC, grab, super, whatever. Five-button controls is no excuse to believe this game doesn't have playstyle. Add RC and there are literally a dozen routes of combo options from the first gatling. Online sets are fast and a flurry of trading the upper hand, full of big moments, hilarious fumbles, and memorable happenstances. And this game keep going. More and more characters are being added, we just got crossplay, balancing updates, I could go on. This game blew up for a reason, because it is quality.

Does this game look good to you? Are you even remotely interested in FGs as a genre? Because, holy shit, do I have a game for you. Welcome to the peak of fighting games; good fun, a fervor to improve, great combo tools, and a presentation that will never get old.

Best fighter currently on the market by several orders of magnitude.
All the early whining about no combos, no gatlings, bad music, and etc. turned out to be just that: whining.
Strive is the gold standard that all other fighting game developers now have to match. Failure to do so, as was seen with Melty blood type Lumina, will end in disaster.
Yes, the netcode is very, very, very good. Unmatched, even. Turns out that when you hire professionals to do your rollback implementation for you, it gives results.

Constant support, DLCs, characters, community interaction, and features at virtually every fighting game event and tournament ever means this might well become the most complete guilty gear.

Edit: years later, the game's still holding strong, and in a better state than ever. Strive put guilty gear on the map, and is proof that Daisuke's vision is 20/20.

Is Guilty Gear Strive worth playing? Yes.
It is quite expensive, but the time spent playing is very enjoyable.

For a fighting game, it is not very difficult picking up the general mechanics.
Usually in fighting games, learning special moves is very difficult for new players.
In strive they made most special moves simple, simply a quarter circle forward or backwards for most moves.
I think it is one of the better games, if you want to get into fighting games.

The visuals are simply outstanding, on of the best looking games of this year.
The art direction in the game is very unique for an anime fighter, none of the characters look or feel the same.
The music is also great, with each character theme portraying the characters well. 

8/10, Great fighting game for new players

Updating this review again. Strive is in a very interesting place in the 2023 FGC. My view on it is far more favorable than it used to be. The floor system can still be easy to climb but it does an amazing job of giving actual beginners a sense of progression. I still wish this title retained a bit more of the heart of the franchise but recognize the smart decision made to reach a larger audience.


[Oh Strive...

I had previously reviewed this shortly after launch and gave it a 7.5. Time has shifted that opinion, along with revisiting the other Guilty Gear titles.

I think history will reflect on this game as the fast food edition of Guilty Gear. Despite all the marketing hype a critical mistake was made developing the game, in that at it's core it abandoned the essence of the series. Instead of mixing in commonly used tools (such as simple input specials and autocombos) to help new players get adjusted, they opted for gutting movement and defensive options, along with reduced movelists. This, along with a critical lack of any single player content (which would ACTUALLY serve to move units and keep casuals invested, but instead they get a Story mode that is just an Anime movie with no interaction) all results in a Guilty Gear that feels like it is only half finished while running at half speed. 

Online offerings could have provided a reason to keep coming back for more despite the more rudimentary gameplay, but even there developers chose to make climbing the highest mountain relatively easy and accessible. Not so much as having a win points, or rank system, there are merely 11 vague skill "floors". If you have basic fighting game skills you can get to floor 7 with ease and the highest rank called "Celestial" is easier to reach than the Gold ranks in Street Fighter. It will look good at first glance, but it won't be long until you find yourself in training mode asking if that's all your character can do, and you'll have the same feeling after finishing a drive-thru cheeseburger.


4.5/10

If you want to play Guilty Gear play Accent Core +R, it seems the community there is growing, especially since it has rollback netcode and is super affordable.

If you want to pick up your first fighting game you'll find far more complete and rewarding experiences in Street Fighter 5 Champion Edition or Mortal Kombat 11.]

This is one of the most fun fighting games I've played, and the best one on the market for sure. The characters are all pretty unique with no real overlap in roles. Most of them are fun to play and fun to play against, with only a few exceptions.
I think this game is especially new player friendly but still with plenty of complexity if you want it. The ranking structure is also really great, with 10 "floors" you can play on, each with its own skill level. You can always go to a higher floor, but can't go below certain floors as your skill improves. This means you have the freedom to keep playing at a higher level if you want to, regardless of what the game thinks, essentially letting you choose your own rank. There's also an unranked area where you can rematch people as many times as you want.
The best part of the game is the netcode. You can reasonably play against people with pings as high as 150 without any discomfort, much better than the absolutely horrible netcode in games like Tekken, SFV, or DBFZ. 
The soundtrack is also great and I would have happily paid $60 just for that.

The biggest downside however, is that a lot of the top characters are so busted that they make the game non-competitive if you don't pick a similar character. Zato, Happy Chaos, and others will put you in constant pressure that will have you trying to block for the entire duration of the round unless you have put an absolutely inordinate amount of time time into learning how to deal with specifically that individual situation.

I, personally love strive. Veterans of the series may dislike it and feel it dumbs down the series' mechanics. I understand why people might dislike it, but I don't really get why people hate it.

Strive is a step towards bringing Guilty Gear to a larger playerbase. It's intuitive, the feedback every time you land a hit is fantastic, and the aesthetic is amazing. It's a great first fighting game for anyone, in my honest opinion. Even beyond that, the roman cancel system has amount of depth to it that gives people trying to master the game something to sink their teeth into. You can't get to higher levels or play without mastering roman cancels, but you don't need to if playing at high levels doesn't interest you. At the end of the day, strive is flashy, fun, and in your face.

There are reasons why people dislike strive, though. There are enough characters with neutral skips to make neutral frustrating or seem irrelevant. The top character, Happy Chaos, is genuinely unfun to fight against. The grab invulnerability on wakeup and after being hit puts an inordinate emphasis on fuzzies. Problems like these are pointed out by high level players, and that's fine. Strive might not be the game for them. Aside from Happy Chaos, there isn't anything glaringly bad about the game worth despising the game for.

I'd recommend anyone newer to fighting games pick up strive, and I'd still recommend that those with more experience pick it up. With over 500 hours in it, I still love it. If you're a fighting game veteran, though, I'd suggest you look hard at the mechanics before you purchase. With Granblue Rising just around the corner, that might be more your speed.

Alright despite my 140 hours of playtime I can't with this game anymore. The balance of the game is so bad to the point where some characters just can't be viable no matter what. Tension gain is way too much in this game and you can't go 5 seconds without having someone do roman cancel and take half of your hp.

For starters I love this series, but I can't keep playing this game. It's too bullshit blazing, RC is the most brain-dead busted thing I have ever seen in any game and allows conversions and borderline TOD off of basically nothing. Everyone dies too fast and meter gains way too fast, especially with positive bonus. In season three already good characters got better due to wild assault, and the not so good ones got left behind. The whole gimmick of wall break on paper sounds good, but the fact that you can get a hard knock down after it with super or wild assault is insane and lets the opponent just reset their pressure while you can do nothing. and positive bonus makes it worse and lets there pressure go on forever. I love you Daisuke but for the love of Christ go play XX Accent Core + or XRD REV 2 if you want a much more balanced, but still at it's core the Guilty Gear experience. I will be playing those from now on since I still absolutely adore this series and the characters. The most left for me here until or if the problems I have are fixed or adjusted is to check out the new characters and play with friends every now and then. #BUFFMYBOYFAUST.

If Street Fighter 6 is the pretty valedictorian, Guilty Gear is the rad alt-punk who takes you to a concert and secretly smoked behind the gym with you.
GG:Strive is, like the series as a whole, "anime maximalism". Everything is cranked up to the maximum while staying incredibly earnest. There are few series with cooler presentation than Guilty Gear and Strive is no different (though Instant Kills were really cool in Xrd, sad they are gone.)

As a relative newcomer to fighting games, I find matches with equally skilled players any time of the day. The training mode misses some features I loved in SF6 (a baked in frame data display for example), but the mission mode does a much better job at teaching the basics of the game than SF6's character guides and tutorial. 

I love how distinct the characters feel and have big trouble deciding on a main, since almost everyone is fun to play. On a competitive level, some characters might be a bit overtuned, but ultimately it's fairly balanced.

Easily the competitive game I’ve sunk my teeth into the most. The community is also fantastic, and competing in tournaments is extremely rewarding. 

My main gripes with the game remain on the accessibility side of things. Colourblindness has hampered my full enjoyment of this fighter, and some of the silhouette work also lacks clarity, without any options to improve this. 

Beyond this however, even though this game is considered simple among fighters, it has boundless depth and countless hours of enjoyment to be found. On top of this, it is easily one of the most gorgeous competitive games out there, especially when it comes to some overdrive animations. This game will probably eventually end up being my most played of all time and I’ll gladly give it that badge.

Guilty Gear is a very important series to me and strive has cemented itself as something i will never forget,
Seeing friends from all walks of life play and work to better themselves at the game stands as a testament to the success of the games mission. STRIVE is more than a subtitle, but a theme at the core of the game that is reinforced by everything inside it, from the story mode, the music, and even the very useless and cheesy and of match analysis the game does for you. The game invites you through its iconic and diverse characters, stays in your memory from its wide array of fantastic music, and keeps you playing and learning with its simple and satisfying game play, all to reinforce its theme of STRIVE-ing to be better.
Strive is not a perfect game by any means, there is plenty to complain about, but at its core lies something to be cherished and remembered, that burning desire to improve that i saw in all of my friends picking up the game, is something that can happen to anyone that picks up the game, and i will never forget the memories I've made, seeing my friends finally kick my ass and being so excited for them despite me losing.
Guilty Gear STRIVE is a game anyone can pick up, something that can inspire anyone to improve, pick it up and have some fun with your friends, i promise fighting games aren't so scary.

This game would be a PERFECT 10/10 were it not for the near abysmal lobby system. The netcode is incredible in matches, the visuals are an industry best, and the characters are varied and deep in terms of gameplay. 
Which is why it is such a shame that the lobby to get to the matches is plagued with the classic ArcSys lobby syndrome of not functioning as it should. At least having the option to have a room with just a list of names (see Marvel vs Capcom Infinite) would be a godsend and would alleviate this issue. 
Other than that, the matches are over fast, but the rematch option is just as fast, keeping you involved and engaged. If you have a friend who you want to play dozens of matches against, this game is for you.

First impressions:

This game rocks! On PC it has been almost flawless. The game is fun to learn for a newbie like myself. The tutorials (missions) are good. This helps newbies like me learn to play better online. 

Teething issues:  Yes, GG Strive has some teething issues, with lobbies as many people have said. But the devs are doing a good job pushing out fixes and updates on a regular basis.

I hope the devs are budgeted to update Strive regularly with bug fixes and lobby improvements rather than only adding DLCs. Why? Because, I think, when the FG community sees responsive devs sorting out game issues on a regular basis, that this helps the Strive FG community feel that they've been heard. This in turn helps the FG community stay engaged and active online.

Wish List: 

1) Keep expanding the tutorial/missions for beginners. New players to FG's are the future.

2) Keep working on making the AI really smart. Find creative ways to have the AI imitate human players of different skill levels so that offline against CPU actually preps you for online play. 

3) Keep making that awesome net-code better and better. It's key because it brings people from far away close together. And I think this builds trust between gamers and developers. A trust that's been lacking in other games that have endless loot box mechanics and pay to win features.

RATING: 8 out of 10 – at the moment. 

Great game!

A very weird take on the GG franchise that throws almost everything out the window in regards to previous entries in the series.

+Visually impressive, stages and character models look great at 4k.

-Lazy and intrusive in game UI
-Soundtrack is mostly washed up deadbeat dad "metal" with a side of absolutely disgraceful vocals
-Weak DLC roster
-Very questionable approach to balance

If you had no attachment to old GG, you'll probably like it. If you played +R or XRD, you might want to stay away from this one.

I made the jump from Accent Core to Strive. Boy, was it a jump. Between learning Street Fighter III: Third Strike and utterly disavowing Tekken in any way, shape or form, GGST won over my heart with its cast of characters, homages to rock, and overall aesthetic. 

Fine, I also thought that I-No, Gio and Ky were hot, okay? I remember not thinking this game was 3D. I was fucking surprised when after a round, I saw Sol up against the stage wall, rendered in glorious 3D. 

"Oh my god."

My friend has been trying to get me to take my playing to a better level, and honestly, as cool as that is, I'm also content to just screw around. But I did decide to take him up on that. And now I hate Anji Mito. 

Oh well. This game splashes with style, slashes with charm, and dusts you with atmosphere, kickass music, and bombastic moves. I've never been so honored to have my ass get kicked in this game. One day, my Ky wil crush Anji. Guess I gotta learn the matchup.

This is a review from someone who hadn't played many fighting games before, but now have sold their body and soul to this hobbie thanks to this game. I hope this is useful for anyone considering giving Guilty Gear Strive a shot, be it a newbie like me or a veteran player of the FG community.
[h1]
[/h1]
[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Great characters[/b] with unique personalities, mechanics and each with it's own song theme (with lyrics). Seriously, you'll fall in love with them.
[*][b]Absolute [i]BANGER[/i] music.[/b]
[*][b]Easy to grasp but hard to master gameplay.[/b] Learning each character moves and mechanics feels rewarding and fun, and you'll [i]never [/i]stop learning.
[*][b]Incredible art style[/b] and one of the most stunning animations I've seen in any video-game. 
[*][b]Good tutorials[/b]. Really useful if you're new to Guilty Gear or fighting games in general (like me).
[*][b]Intuitive guide for the lore[/b]. In case you like to read hours of convoluted lore and character background, the [i]Guilty Gear World Mode[/i] got you covered. You can also just ignore that, read a wiki or watch some videos, but hey, it's cool to have that in the actual game.
[*][b]Honestly it's just so addictive and fun[/b]. If you like anime, good music and complex combat mechanics, this game is everything you could've asked for.
[/list]


[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Unstable servers. [/b]It can take a while to find matches and sometimes you'll just get a network error out of nowhere. Didn't happen much to me, but it's important to notice
[*][b]Bad multiplayer interface.[/b] It's unnecessarily convoluted, buggy and also flawed in assigning players to their skill level.
[*][b]Literally unplayable story-mode. [/b]This mode is just an hours-long cutscene with no gameplay, no previous context for new players, and overall just poor a script even for a fully cinematic experience. Really disappointing considering how much potential it had.
[*][b]Outrageous prices for the Season Pass.[/b] Almost half of the character roster are behind a paywall (with more to be added in the following season, and not counting the arenas and extra colors) and the prices of each Season Pass [i]doubled[/i] since I bought the game. I really hope they lower the price soon because this just makes the game content so fucking expansive.
[/list]


[h1]My experience with the game[/h1]
Guilty Gear Strive was my real introduction to the fighting games community. I've never been that interested in the genre and the thought of getting into it was scary, due to it's competitive nature and complicated mechanics. A few months ago, I didn't even know what "neutral" meant in a FG context. And to my own surprise, my journey through the game (and the many others that I've decided to explore after) couldn't be more fun and engaging.
To be clear, what got me into GGST wasn't the gameplay, but the soundtrack and characters. I bet anyone can just listen to a few songs and get to know some of the cast to start yearning to learn how to play, just to experience the whole thing. To me it was Baiken, Bridget and May. To you it could be Sol, Nagoriyuki, Testament, Johnny... Even if you know nothing about the lore, the charisma of these characters and the songs associated with them is endearing enough to captivate you.
The thing is, the gameplay simply encapsulates the essence of it's visuals and music, turning the whole experience into a perfect amalgamation of anime art, combat, and rock music. You can feel the beat of the music, the power of each attack, the spectacle of the fight... Honestly it didn't feel all that difficult to grasp. After learning the basics and beating the Arcade Mode on the Hard Route, it almost felt like it wasn't all that complicated of a game. Then I saw what more experienced players can do, and I started to understand what a competitive fighting game feels like.
And the best part? Being defeated by random players that are better than me wasn't demotivating at all. A bit scary, for sure, but it opened my eyes to how much there is to master in this game. Unlike many competitive games I tried, this one made me want to keep playing even after facing defeat. Because it [i]felt good[/i] to play with those characters.
Each one of them is interesting in it's own way, although each person will have their own taste. It could be their design, their personality, their lines, a specific move, their mechanics... My first "main" was May, but as much as I love her, Baiken was the character I REALLY wanted to play with. Since I couln't pay for the Season Pass, I bought her DLC individually just to try her out. It made the game 200% more fun, I've been playing non-stop since, grinding every week. Boy I love this game.
Now, considering that the characters are the soul of this game, one would think that the Story Mode would be phenomenal... Unfortunately, that's [i]by far[/i] the weakest part of it, making it my biggest disappointment with this game. Instead of an interactive experience, with good writing and using the amazing music that you listen during the matches, what you get is essencialy a 3D animated movie that is way longer than it should be, with zero context for new players (besides a wiki-style guide that lectures you through the massive lore of the series), convoluted plot, unbearable pacing and an awful animation that feels really out of place considering how good the rest of the game looks. Upon visiting the game, my first impression was that Guilty Gear had great potential for an action anime or manga series: memorable characters, interesting (albeit wacky) story, outstanding soundtrack and great visuals. How could they mess up this part [i]that bad [/i]is simply beyond me. I'd say without hesitation that the soundtrack has a more interesting storytelling than the actual Story Mode.
Does that make the single-player experience terrible? I don't think so. The Arcade Mode is still fun and shows interesting interactions between the characters, and the tutorial missions can teach useful lessons. Besides, you'll always go back to the competitive play. When you jump into online matches, test your skill with other players and learn with your mistakes, that's where the fun is. I couldn't see myself that engaged with a multiplayer game before, but here I am.

[h1]In conclusion[/h1]
My advice to new players is, just pick the character that resonates with you and don't be afraid to face the mayhem. If this is your first fighting game, you've picked the right one. It's intuitive and has the right amount of complexity to make it interesting, while also having the most unique visuals and soundtrack you'll find in the genre. Keep playing and maybe you'll start getting deeper into the FG lexicon, grinding your skills to new levels and start to look up to bigger challanges... Before you know it, you'll already be blazing through matches and addicted to the smell of the game.

Note: The review has changed into a positive review since the 3rd of April; before then was a negative since launch.

※June 22, 2021
It's definitely a good game, I'll give it that. It's just that I can't get into it as much as Blazblue or UNI. I have played other Guilty Gear games albeit not all on Steam, but those were pretty fun in their own way. This game does feel like Guilty Gear in some parts and sometimes feels very different, which I know what is going for. The visuals are amazing and the music is sick, but the gameplay, especially the lobbies, and sometimes the UI give me a slight bit of sourness in my mouth. The game does feel okay at best, the UI dosen't really work for me, and the lobbies are straight up awful. The player matches in the Steam version didn't even function until a patch was rolled out. I would recommend it to newer folk, but as a game right now, I wouldn't recommend it at full price. Let's see what the patches would do to it.

※September 10, 2021
After 3 months and patches, it sure has improved especially since the most recent one. Characters feel more fleshed out except for the bottom tiers, and the networking is slightly better than last time. It still has a quite annoyingly long "connecting to server", and after getting used to the gameplay systems, it's not as expressive as other fighting games, but it plays good enough to have fun. Overall, it's still not worth 60$.

※April 3, 2022
The Season 1 Pass has been completed, and these new characters are pretty OD. This game has become much more advanced with many new discoveries that have made a pretty okay game to a very in-depth, and surprisingly fast fighting game. This game has evolved and become a phenomenal game, and I can confidently say that this game has become one of the best new fighting games in the past few years.

Favorite fighting game

Mmm, do you smell that? Guilty Gear -Strive- is yet the latest in the Guilty Gear franchise, offering a great entry point for newbies while still offering much to master. One of those "low skill floor, high skill ceiling" kinda games. Be warned: you may need to build up those skills before successfully tackling Arcade Mode, but Mission Mode exists to teach you many things.

Online's got rollback, skill-based matchmaking, even background matchmaking (so you can practice combos while waiting for a match). You will be assessed on how well you can take down an AI Sol, and assigned a tower floor which has other players your level. You may venture higher if you think you're up for the challenge, but cannot go lower than your floor (unless you're in Celestial, I guess).

There are also a few lesser features for which items can be unlocked:
• Avatar customization (how you're seen online)
• Gallery (to be filled with artworks, music, and even trailers)
• Room furniture (for custom lobbies)
• Digital figure (you can arrange models however you please to take photos and share them online)
items for these features are obtained through fishing. Or in other words, a gacha mechanic. Spend the World Dollars you get from playing online or clearing missions in order to fish.

This game has just 15 characters, not counting DLC. As of Season 3, there is a confirmed 13 DLC characters. That's... an alarming ratio. That's 46.43%!! In any case, they each come with some banger tunes. The whole soundtrack's an banger, really.

Oh, and there's a story movie. Also a glossary, correlation chart, and chronology for your perusal. I've gotten my fair share of use out of all of them, being an aspiring loremaster.

No tl;dr, sorry.

Game is still bad, and it will be forever bad
But I'll still play it, because I probably like it. Such thing is fate.

My original review is below, but as of June 2023...

Due to some... complications, the online for this game has reached a level of inconsistency that is no longer acceptable. There are no exceptions: if the online modes for your primarily-multiplayer game don't work, you get a thumbs down. This game was in a pretty great spot before the problems with online started, and I hope the team is seriously working hard to provide a fix.

I've heard the problems are being caused by a cyber-attack, then I heard it was an issue with adding cross-play into the mix post-launch. Either way, it doesn't matter to me: the lobby system was pushing it as far as online play was concerned, and now on top of all the previous problems it just doesn't work. I've been on board for the additional 2 seasons of content, but I don't see myself buying into another season's worth of content if the problems aren't fixed.

Best of luck, ArkSys. I'm looking forward to the day I can edit this review back to a positive one.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

OG Review:
I love fighting games, but have never messed with anime fighters for more than a few weeks at a time. I've kept coming back to this one after about a year, so I'd say it's a winner.

Pros
+ presentaion is outstanding
+ gameplay trims the fat of most anime fighters while maintaining complexity for plenty of room to grow
+ tutorials on fighting game basics are thorough and plentiful
+ online netcode is great (finally they show us the ping!)
+ Combo creator is a clever addition that can keep you occupied for hours on end
+ story mode is just a movie basically... but at least it's a pretty good movie
+ feels like something different for the anime fighter subgenre

Cons
- story mode requires 2+ hours of youtube studying if you haven't touched the series before
- online lobby system to get into matches is half-busted ("failed to connect to duel station" is way too common). please just give us regular matchmaking, please for the love of God ArkSys stop it with the lobbies.
- no combo trials from the dev team (might take some time to weed through the not-so-great ones in the combo maker mode, or ones that are obsolete because of updates)
- massive jump in online ranked skill between floor 10 and "heaven," many players are complaining about the entry system that must be "earned" to get into heaven every month. Because there are no floors at the heaven rank, intermediates are thrown into the arena with the best of the best, which isn't always the best way to learn.

As far as fighting games go this one's still an easy 5 out of 5. If you're an anime fan and all those Naruto/Demon Slayer/One Piece fighters keep letting you down, try this. You won't be disappointed.

Guilty Gear Strive is the best fighting game I have ever played. 
It is a beautifully stylistic amalgamation of 2D and 3D.
It's easy to pick up with simple systems but allows for near-infinite complexity through the Roman Cancel.
Guilty Gear as a series is just plain fun - the fluid movement and systems allow for fast and creative gameplay with unlimited player expression.
I've played the series for about 250 hours so far and am just now reaching the highest rank, Celestial, and there is so much more to learn.
Would highly recommend for anyone with any level of experience in fighting games.

Absurdly long review I wrote for some reason:

A pretty decent anime style fighting game. The soundtrack is excellent and the gameplay can be very fun at times. In addition, the graphics and animation are also excellently done.  

In contrast to the game’s marketing, there is very little story and singleplayer content. The game’s “story mode” is just one extremely long cutscene and another fairly long cutscene (which I honestly don’t mind that much (and most users shouldn't even try to watch in the first place)). On singleplayer content, there are about 3 things you can do alone; “survival mode”, “arcade mode”, and “vs cpu”. Survival mode is a (boring) infinite series of player vs ai matches. Once every 10 or so opponents are defeated, you face off against a “boss” opponent. This goes on until you die. Arcade mode is a short (also boring) series of 8 player vs ai matches, with some story surrounding the character you use. Finally for singleplayer content, the “vs cpu” mode is a single match against an ai opponent who is using a character of your choosing. 

However, the real meat and bones of this game’s play time comes not from the singleplayer content. The multiplayer in this game is well done. I have had quite a lot of fun playing this game with friends. For the most part, this game is balanced enough to the point where no character is very noticeably better than another. Now as I have said, I have had a lot of fun playing this game with friends. Friends who live very long distances from me, and I have the netcode to thank for that. The netcode on this game is very good (as is most rollback), which results in smoother online play. You can also load into online matches with random people. The ranking system for random matches online is not all that great, but it is just fine, and does its job. The gameplay has enough depth, I can’t really say more as enjoyment is subjective. 

Unfortunately, now, we get to my biggest issue with the game and ultimately a deciding factor for many users. The price. This is a $40 game, which is fine, if not a bit expensive. The real issue is the DLC. The DLC systems are very annoying, resulting in, for example, getting a cast about half the size of BlazBlue: Centralfiction’s for nearly twice the price. Insane.

CONCLUSION:

In conclusion, this is a good game, with a lot of fun to be had with its excellent netcode, fun gameplay, and amazing soundtrack. Sadly, it is weighed down by a heavy price tag for a low character count, and has paid DLC.

CONCLUSION CONCLUSION:

It’s good, but expensive. If you can, get it on sale.

As much as I love this game, I simply [u][b]can NOT recommend it at its current price[/b][/u]. In case you aren't aware, as of the 24th of August 2023, ArcSys has made the incredible decision of getting rid of regional pricing in some countries.
Here is what this means in practice:
[list]
    [*]Some countries were hit with ridiculous price increases. We got hit with a 2x price increase, and I'm starting to think we were lucky. People from other countries reported they got hit with 3x, 4x, 5x, 6x and even [u][b]a mind boggling 10x price increase[/b][/u]. Really, it would be funny if it weren't so sad.
    [*]This also means that, [u][b]in some places, Strive by itself with no DLC is more expensive than it was on launch[/b][/u]. In our case it was R$ 129.99 back in 2021, and now it is R$ 179.99. The previous price on the day before this new change was R$ 86.99 btw, so it really more than doubled for us.
    [*]And since everything doubled, [u][b]a season pass now costs even more than the base game did just a couple of days ago[/b][/u]. Previously for us it was R$ 56.99, and now it is R$ 107.99. So basically, season 3 costs 20 bucks more than the base game for people that got the game before August 24 lol. I bought the Ultimate Edition back in May, and got the game + seasons 1 and 2 + a bunch of new character colors for a discounted price of R$ 122.49. It is simply impossible for me to justify spending so much on S3, and unless there's a sale or the prices get readjusted, I might skip it entirely. Hell, might drop the game completely even. I'm not interested in keeping up with a game where I can't afford any of the new content lol.
    [*]Btw, here's a fun fact: [u][b]some people have reported that in their region, this new season pass costs as much if not more than Street Fighter 6[/b][/u], which is an entirely *new* fighting game game with substantially more content than Strive lol
[/list]
Overall, it really feels like ArcSys is actively trying to kill Strive at this point, and if this is the case, I wish them the best of luck in their endeavours lmao. Because I'm not sure what raising the prices for people in poorer countries accomplishes. Sure, it might make them more money, but that means even less of us can actually afford it. And I don't know if you guys are aware, but for a game with dogshit single player content (story modes are just big movies and not even playable, and arcade and training modes are literally the bare minimum these days) in a genre where the multiplayer aspect is the most important component, having more players is very very important. Vital even, you might say lol. As of the time of me writing this comment (25/08/2023), they still haven't addressed the issue in any way, shape or form. Funny enough they did already talk about fixing Faust's banana crashing the game lol.

So idk, pray for a sale or a price change if you are really interested in this and live in a country with garbage economy. Just be aware that the online might be completely dead by then lmao.

Edit (26/08/2023): I have just checked and it seems that the soundtracks (Necessary Discrepancy 1 & 2) didn't have their prices altered in any region at all? I'm not sure if this means anything, but it could possibly indicate that the new pricing is an error? But given the lack of official acknowledgement, I wouldn't count on it though.

[strike]Edit (10/09/2023): ArcSys has a survey about season 3 going on (you can find a link on their GG twitter @GUILTYGEAR_PR). If the price change has affected you too, PLEASE considering telling them through there as well. Survey closes on the 14th of September. Let's hope they listen.[/strike]

Edit (28/09/2023): Well, it's been over a month now and the price hasn't been reverted or at least lowered. It's very safe to assume that this is the new price and it won't be changed.

Guilty Gear Strive was my introduction to the Guilty Gear series. I started playing it about six months ago, a little while before the release of Asuka. Its the first 'serious' fighting game I've ever played, assuming you don't count platform fighters like Smash or my very short look at Persona 4 Arena. It went from just some new fighting game to my second most played game on Steam, and easily my favorite fighting game of all time. Shortly after getting into this game, I went back and played all the previous Guilty Gear games on Steam, save for Isuka. My most played is still Strive by far, but I've put a bit of time into all of them. I figured I would preface all of that before explaining what makes the game good.

Here are all the reasons this game deserves your 40 dollars plus DLC.

-Gameplay-
Strive is a very beginner friendly fighting game with a low skill floor. It was the first serious fighting game I ever played, but I improved quickly and did well. Just about anyone can launch the game and pick someone like May or Faust and be alright from the get go, so long as they understand how inputs work. Even without knowing special inputs, some characters can get away with just their normal attacks. It's not hard to learn, and even if you're completely new to the game, you'll get the hang of it faster than you probably expect. That said, if you try and go any higher than floor 4 or 5 with such little skill, you will naturally get your shit rocked. You need to learn how the game works before you can get up that high, unless you're playing an easy character. The unique Roman Cancel system, along with the Burst system and the new mechanics added in Season 3, make any character, simple or technical, have a lot of depth. There are still optimal characters and best ways to play, but there isn't really a 'bad' character in the game. Any character can get good results online if you yourself know how to play them.

-Music-
Of course I had to talk about music. People joke that this game is actually a 40 dollar soundtrack with a free game tacked on, and I would have to agree with them. This game's music is amazing. I personally buy a lot of Steam Soundtracks, since they're higher quality than I could find on YouTube or Spotify. This game alone has one of the best soundtracks I've heard in a long while, even ignoring songs from the older games. There isn't much more to say, just a really good soundtrack.

-Characters-
The characters in this series have really great designs, personalities, and are really fun. It would take way too long to describe them all, so just play the game.

-Community-
This game is still very alive. It was at Evo for the past few years, it has a massive online following, and there are still thousands of people playing. The community that surrounds this game is one of the kindest game communities I've ever been part of.


In closing, just buy it if you're on the fence. It's a great game. It has some network issues at times, and random quiet price increases are scummy, but I feel that the pros outweigh the cons.

If this is your first fighting game, go for it. You're going to have an amazing time, and you will learn a lot.

If you're a more experienced player who values depth and open-ended systems, play +R instead.

Ridiculous buffer and bizarre input reader, design decisions that turn matchups into streamlined flowcharts with little room for player expression and outside-the-box playstyles, oversimplification of classic GG design, like removal of air untech, limited gatlings, massive neutral skips and mostly grounded gameplay, fullscreen burst and character specific streamlining (baikens guard cancels + baku followups turned into a mashable 1frame parry?!), 
all those changes made me dislike the game more the better I got at it.

PS: Happy Chaos is not the problem. Overall design principles of Strive are the problem.

The Worst mainline (and possibly the worst in general) Guilty Gear. 

Take everything that made the older games great and throw it out the window and you get Strive. The only good thing I can really compliment is the Graphics but not anything else. ArcSys tried to sell the game as a neutral heavy game just to slowly retract that statement over time, ESPECIALLY with the combo training mode. The point of the extremely high damage was to emphasize that point. The Damage thing is just also not really a fun thing. 

The soundtrack is repetitive, this would be fixed if nearly the entire soundtrack wasn't lyrical since the lyrics can get really repetitive as well. When Sky Should Be High is the best song in the game you know you did something wrong. (Not trying to say that's a bad song or anything)

Bringing back older characters as paid DLC is something that just shouldn't exist (Can't really knock on strive specifically since most fighting games do this)

There's also just the fact that the game was made to "appeal to casuals" which I can understand what they're trying to do but it only hurts the game. Especially when Xrd Games were already easier than the Accent Core games, which were extremely difficult to play. This actively makes you worse as a fighting game player considering that it has you adapt to an easier environment. Which also gives you the demoralizing mindset of getting washed in any game with more complexity, considering how you have to work more to achieve results. 

In all honesty, we should've just gotten a Rev 3.

Worse than Rev 2.
I struggle to find what else to say, this series just appears to get less and less wacky with each instalment.

I played X and Accent Core as a kid, immediately enamoured with the soundtrack, characters and presentation.
I've always been a little sad at some things that got removed between that and Revelator, but Rev has so many of its own cool features to make the changes worth it.

Every character in Strive feels like they've been nerfed, like they've just forgotten a bunch of moves they used to know for the sake of balance, and though they've done quite a decent job at re-balancing the experience around these changes, I still cannot agree that it is a better experience overall - In the end, that's all I want from a sequel, for it to be better than (and probably have more stuff) than the previous entry.

It looks prettier than Rev 2, breaking walls in the corner shakes up the combat nicely, and some inputs feel a bit easier to do with marginally better sound design in some areas.
That said, the music isn't so much better as it is just different now that it includes lyrics (The GG soundtracks have always been drowning in bangers) and so there just aren't all that many improvements, especially with such a small roster of characters. It's much easier to learn, and maybe that's the purpose of it - If you're new to the series, I guess take this as a recommendation? I would still recommend playing a simpler fighting game first to grasp the basics.

The new characters are pretty cool at least, and I look forward to seeing them all get Zappa'd in the next Guilty Gear, hah.

Also I suppose it would be remiss of me not to mention that Testament being a trans woman is awesome, makes perfect sense in context of the plot, and is a wondrously welcome addition to the series that is by no means necessary, but doesn't detract either - Testament's boring-ass new moveset? Not so much.
...I say this mainly to preface that I think I would've preferred to have some non-offensive, non-joke femboy/enby representation in the form of Bridget, but I guess things could be way worse on that front, lol. So I s'pose I'm happy enough about that too, even if it doesn't make the game worth playing.

This is probably one of my favorite PvP games, and it's unfortunate I will still never recommend it. Not in its current state. Because when you purchase this, you're not getting Guilty Gear - The Game, but rather Guilty Gear - Lobby Simulator. And by the looks of things it will be multiple years and possibly in the game's end-of-life when that will be fixed. If at all. A year later, and a new season pass is being sold, yet not a single change in sight to the matchmaking system and their "improvements" to server connection times still lead to 30+ sec start screen waiting from the EU. Yes, you sit on the start screen for almost a minute (It was much worse before, i didn't bother testing it with the update because it will still long enough).
But I'm sure they'll keep cranking out characters, make new season passes and more. If you think you only care about the core fighting game experience, this will be a great game for you. Me personally, I can't sit through their shit lobbies, shitty networking design, shittier matchmaking experience and equally as shit everything else. I'll possibly return to it when they fix this hot mess (looking like when its dead), if I'm not already busy with my huge backlog of other games to play that actually respect my time. 
One other small thing that you can take from what you will. I was looking through SteamDB and saw Skyrim still has a min 14k players (SE, not including the old one). A single player game. Meanwhile this has a max of 8k. But of course, its different genres, every other FG sits at similar numbers (T7, SFV, MK11), and its not an apples to apples to comparison. Even then, I do think I'd rather go play Skyrim than this lobby game. Guess I'll just use Elden Ring to scratch my PvP itch.

Started in X2, Enjoyed Accent Core, Fell in love with Xrd. Strive is an enjoyable if somewhat off-centre addition to the library of Guilty Gear.

Let me start by saying this game is good fun. Press buttons, cool stuff happens. The Cast is incredibly eye catching and filled with personality, the mechanics are simple and gameplay is fast and flashy no matter how new you are to the game. As a bonus - even If you are getting into the game - it's not too late, just be ready to know that the "honeymoon" period of this game sailed off two years ago. However the game at it's core is very easy to pick up, fun as part of fighting game mastery and can times be absolutely hilarious with the right crew of people.

However as we approach year 3, the original things that made it great are starting to show their own issues. In particular match-making is starting to stutter. I had the option of playing S1 on PS5 very early on and it was crazy how packed the rooms were; you could get a match pretty much instantly and you were never pitted against someone who'd outright smoke you because everyone was in the same boat. Nowadays and Notably; Anything below level 7 in Tower (effectively the Elo System to have you fight players at your skill level) is beginning to get empty and getting a string of games against varied opponents to improve your skill is less frequent (still enough around though).  The player base is what I'd say "still healthy" for a fighting game this old but far from its first few months (peaking around a 1/3rd of what it once was on new patch day), But Ideally one of the next steps for Arc systems is to collapse the number of Tower levels from 10 to around 5 and find a way of keeping matchups as close as possible.

Now Don't get me wrong this is just a natural part of game life and the game is fun, but it has some other issues. First it's the damage. S1 & S2 Damage output was insane in this game with two-touches quite common (especially for Chipp players). Season 3 has seen a slight reduction of damage, but even a suboptimal combo can land you a good 30% off someones lifebar without any real effort; and the damage you take just regular blocking is still crazy high - Yes there's a mechanic to mitigate this but good lord do bodies drop quickly. Next is the combo-routing: the game got "solved" quite quickly because damage and combos were so high and easy to do, due to this as new characters have popped in and others received buffs/nerfs not that much has shifted. They also changed the "Gatling" system - a combo system in older games, up a bit - I can't tell if this is good are bad. It's good because there's less of an auto-combo system in place, but bad in that it's more about knowing to do what combo when rather than random routing off a lucky counter-hit.  

Third issue is that Arc System works seem reluctant to shake things up and I can understand why - deviate too much and you annoy the loyalists; however Street Fighter 6, Tekken 8, MK 1 are all out / or coming out; and and at this point SF6 has pretty much redefined the bar when it comes to content in a fighting game. For GG to remain competitive it needs something to make it stand out - what that will be though is hard to say. I mean it does come with whats basically an anime movie, the lootbox game of fishing is a cool distraction, and missions really help develop your game knowledge. However beyond that there's very little stuff to "do" other than hop online and alot of people don't want that.

Next is the cool but not really helpful combo-learning system. Back in XRD you had missions and trials to work through with each character. Strive "sort of" has this - in the sense that the community make these trials through the combo builder system. This is great as you can get everything from "oh wow I didn't know you could do that" moments to absolute meme/trolling types, however you can't help but feel it would have been really handy to have about x10 Arc-System implemented tutorials for each character for you to get a solid foundation for each of them and then have the creation mode be what topped/built/theory crafted characters to the next level.  

Final issue is the price - fighting games have gone beyond tolerable in cost now for what you get. The Base game is around £37 GBP at time of writing, but over £90 for the seasons passes bundle (i.e. extra characters) and a load of colour swaps. Nothing really changed across the seasons other than the roster and title screen - no new game modes or features. That makes it a Hard nope if you want to buy and own it now - so as usual the advice for something this old is wait for a sale; if the base game is sub-£30 and the season bundle around £60 you've got a good deal; above that you are just fuelling a really lame business model that seems to be in every fighting game these days.

So Overall where does that leave Strive? Personally I'm still on the fence about this game - 2/3rd's of it I love, the remaining 1/3rd is indifference or distaste. End of the day I would recommend it to people at the right price and doubly so if you just like Arc Systems / Anime / Fighting Games. Early on as a new player you will be allured by the visuals, as you grow into it you'll like what you can do with the combat system (the Roman Cancel system is really what makes GG stand out mechanically); and when you really know the game you'll enjoy what High level in tower can offer. Also for an anime-style fighter (which are typically degenerate messes) it's pretty solid and it's only at higher game-play levels gaps in characters start to show; but for a laid-back play with friends or like-skilled players any character is viable.

Overall super solid.

If you're not accustomed to fighting games, then this will be significantly better with friends. This pretty much applies to every fighting game out there and Strive isn't any different. All of the hours above were spent messing around with friends in private lobbies, it is easily some of the most fun I've had in a fighting game. so gather some friends if you can before making a purchase like this. Or get Xbox PC pass, where it's just $11 AUD a month.

this game is ridiculously accessible and easy to learn. However, online connection can be abysmal (at least for me) and the ranking system isn't very good (Arc Sys has stated they will fix this). Character designs and art direction is off the charts, music is insane and the lore is certainly something (I made a presentation for my friends based on the main character, it ended up being an hour long). 

In the end, if you want an anime fighter that uses short, high damage combos, then this is for you. If your new to fighting games, I would highly recommend some further research and friend gathering. if your coming from other fighting games, then welcome, I hope you enjoy your time here.

Too many characters feel the same. You need to swap to a vastly different character archetype for the characters to feel like they have a substantially different gameplan.

Ranked is completely awful--elo has been around for decades and works, please use it.

Input parser feels completely nonfunctional often and screen freeze buffer windows don't make sense--it doesn't feel like I'm in control of my character.

Too much extremely specific counterplay is expected matchup knowledge e.g. If your counterplay involves consistently using an instant faultless defense, the offensive mechanic in question is too powerful--instant faultless is too conditional for something that requires that you stop blocking.

Positive Bonus is also one of the worst designed snowball mechanics in any fighting game leading to inescapable checkmates due to chip damage even with a reasonable amount of remaining health. The fact that you get this buff after dealing a massive amount of damage and the cost is just resetting to neutral (or if you break with an Overdrive being PLUS THIRTY-SIX WHY?). Corner pressure isn't so valuable in a game with frame 2 throws, you should almost always break the wall, but you get immensely rewarded for doing so.

Strive is probably one of the better games that has been simplified compared to others.
I'll be honest I prefer Xrd Rev 2's system of combat regardless of how complicated that game is and this is because each character has so many options and combo possibilities.

However I'll admit that Rev 2 and Accent Core Plus R can be stressful games.
Strive in its simplicity kind of helps ease things up a bit for me.
If I take a break from Guilty Gear a month or two I need only to start up Strive and start picking back up what I may have forgotten.

And then when I spend time relearning or learning new things it has massive benefits.
I got back to the other games a little more confident.

I do need to also mention something else I appreciate about Strive. I don't need to buy two different versions of the game if I want to play with someone on another platform. Strive handles cross play very surprisingly well. I got to play with an old friend of mine I haven't seen in a while on PlayStation 4 and we grinded several hours on this game just like we used to on BlazBlue and Guilty Gear Xrd Rev 2 years ago.

I'm going to sound like a broken record now because what I'm about to say, others have said too.
But for how much I enjoy Strive I do hate that many of the characters and their combos are a little too simplified. 

I play Baiken in several games. I like how she plays here very much, her new parry is a welcomed and much appreciated addition to her move list. But I wish she kept her old parry and parry dash too.

It feels very off to no longer at least some of the old strategies she had in other games.
In fact I feel its a shame she can't combine her old stuff with the new.

I am grateful however that Strive didn't go the same way as Dragon Ball FighterZ and just give us a ton of auto combos. Granted that game can have very creative combo options too and its fun.
But auto combos do not help anyone new to your fighting game. In fact it ruined my ability to grasp and realize the combo potentials there or be able to learn to fight certain online match ups.

So thank you Strive for not doing that. So long as you stick to your roots even with the new stuff I'll keep coming back. Still hoping for next season all characters get some new move from the old games. Or maybe the next sequel they would bring back the complexity we enjoyed in Xrd Rev 2 and expand upon the new stuff the Strive introduced.

Lastly I'll give praise to the animation quality and soundtrack. Strive's a beast of a game.
If you're new to Guilty Gear and reading this review, give this game a try as it will be a good start into this series especially with its simpler gameplay. You might find yourself going back to older games like Rev 2 after to put your skills to the test.

Update: Not recommended until they fix regional prices

I think now that it's been half a year and Strive maintained a decent enough playerbase it's safe to call it a succesful continuation of the Guilty Gear franchise and something that clearly attracted a lot of new players or returned old ones.

For the most part it's well deserved. The presentation and animations are wonderful. Music for the most part is great. The netcode is fantastic, and characters feel generally good to play. Despite all the problems I have with the game it's a solid FG to jump into for anyone looking for something new or looking for their first fighting game.

That said, there's plenty of issues with Strive even after several patches. Some are a result of rushed development, others are just design decisions that I personally dislike. Most notably the loading times are still terrible. Even if the community mostly solved the issue thanks to Totsugeki app, ArcSys showed little care for the playing experience for anyone outside Japan. Even the most recent patch that adressed loading times only aimed to improve it for USA audience which is honestly insulting.

Outside of that there's some problems with stability of the game. While game itself doesn't crash (at least for me), the netplay experience is hindered by a multitude of errors, dysfunctional lobbies and weird disconnects. I honestly think the game would have more players if Strive was delayed but came out with lobbies that work.

Speaking of lobbies, along custom combo creation tool that was teased pre-launch, lobby customization is one of the thing that's yet to make it into the game thanks to Strive clearly coming out ahead of the schedule. While these are not major issues, they are still issues.

Things that are present also took a minor downgrade compared to Xrd, most notably the training mode that doesn't teach you nearly as much and the combo trials that are largely terrible and don't do a good job of preparing you to fight no life larries and wi-fi demons. This would be fine if custom combo sharing was a thing but we're still waiting.

When it comes to design, I'm honestly nowhere near good enough to have a nuanced and credible opinion on it but I personally hate how much damage everything deals in Strive. To me, a fighting game is way more fun when you can't die from 2-3 combos and strategy has more value, which might sound even less credible when coming from a Tekken fan. Still, it never feels good to eat a random poke or a counter hit and see your lifebar file for a divorce. It doesn't help that defensive mechanics in Strive are not as deep as Xrd's. No blitz, no dead angle, YRC costs as much as a super, instant block is so strict that even pros can't use it effeciently.

Ranked system is one of the worst in gaming. I feel quite confident in saying that because I've never experience anything worse. You know how traditionally games use a system like ELO or GLICKO to figure out your skilla and assign you an MMR? Well, Strive doesn't care about that, it's too Rock and Roll for it. Instead you got 10 floors + Celestial where you can do a special 5 wins in a row challenge to prove you're second Diego Umijuarez. Words cannot describe how bad it is. You can always ascend to floor 10 if you want, you just can't play below your floor, which means everyone is basically at 10 no matter their skill. Celestial is also just same floor 10 players who got lucky and played a favorable matchup or farmed worse players. To call it ranked is a joke but it's the best we have unfortunately. 

The mess doesn't stop on that. If you que by going into the tower itself not only does it waste time, but it also allows people to preview what character you play, allowing them to easily dodge any bad matchup or character they don't like. Terrible decision.

The removal of gatlings is also super questionable to me. While it's easy to get used to, it does make offense a bit more boring all around to me compared to how it was in other games. 

Lastly, I'm not a fan of some character changes. Not cause of anybody getting weaker/stronger but just cause they feel a bit more sterile compared to previous iterations. Strive still got its own kind of sauce but it just doesn't feel as exciting. 

Now to reiterate, I still think the game is fun and worth jumping into. Netcode is great, population seems mostly stable and might even grow after offline tournaments or least 1 DLC character that's not lame as hell. The game needs a lot of improvements but if you're into fighting games, you kinda know that we have to eat a spoon of garbage for a drop of honey and this is the smallest spoon of garbage we've had in a long time. That said, if Xrd had this netcode and comparable amount of players, I'd probably not touch Strive.

Coming from Dragon Ball FighterZ, the transition into Guilty Gear hasn't been too hard, maybe because I'm a genius or something 😎.  But, if you like fighting games that have a bit of footsies and whatnot, then this game is for you. Think of the combo game in Strive as 25% DBFZ and 75% SF. Additionally, don't forget to include one of the games major mechanics "Roman Cancels" which allow you to make any move in your character's arsenal plus on block, make a whiffed move safe, extend combos, and a get off me tool, similar to Dragon Ball's spark mechanic but mid-combo. In this game the roster only consists of 15 characters, however, those characters are extremely different from one another. I can definitely see myself playing this game for years. In conclusion, if you like fighting games, get the damn game.

I love this game. The style, the combat, the characters, and omg the legacy. I can't believe this carried fighting games through 2021-2022 but it did an amazing job. Even though SF6 is out I always find my self coming back.

As a casual fighting game player this is some of the most fun I've had in this genre. By the team who gave us Dragon Ball FighterZ and GrandblueVS, you get 15 unique and over the top characters, a 5 hour long anime series and a really good rock album all in one package. It does have problems, like the time it takes to connect in menus is eternal and the game is somewhat lacking in singleplay content, but even if just for the online experience, this game is more than worth it.

Updated thoughts:
2 years later, the base game is cheaper, most of the connection issues have been ironed out, We have crossplay and 9 amazing dlc characters, with at least 4 more on the way. If you have any interest, there's no better time then now.

[h1]Guilty Gear Strive is a fighting game made by ArcSystem Works launched June 11th 2021. It is the most successful entry in the 25-year-old franchise and for a good reason. This game will certainly be a main stay in the FGC for years to come[/h1]


 [b]Presentation [/b]
   As I mentioned before in the Street Fighter 6 review, Guilty Gear Strive is a game that knows what it wants to be. I am not familiar with the franchise, so my opinions and thoughts would be just about this particular title, but I can say for sure that this game has style. Beautiful cell shaded graphics alongside an amazing original soundtrack and sound design. It has artistic merit all along the way. Not only that but the character design is top tier, and when compared with games like Tekken, KoF and MK it is clear that this game is far superior in that regard. 


 [b]Features [/b]
    There are four ways to fight people in this game: ranked mode, for fun, local and at player lobbies. The most interesting of these four is ranked mode's implementation. The ranked mode revolves around "floors" instead of an Elo. You start ranked against a CPU opponent that measures your power level and puts you on a floor. There are 11 floors in the game, 1 to 10 and then the celestial floor. The higher the floor number, the higher the skill of its players. Floor placement is way more fluid and dynamic than elo: you can go up or down in a matter of hours, so consistent play is way more important. One bad day and all your work can go to nothing. While a bit cruel, this system can give the sensation of a true "ascension" and journey, with highs and lows, so, because of that, I consider it a more interesting way of showing progression in the game.
    Training, arcade and tutorials are very well made as well. You can even create and save your own combos, watch old matches and try to fight against an almost invincible final arcade boss. My only complaint is with the story mode: There is nothing to play, only a literal 4 hour movie. Since story mode is not a very important or strong part of most fighting games i can let it pass, but it is still a little disappointing. 


 [b]Gameplay [/b]
Guilty Gear Strive has the gattling system:

- Punch (P) cancels into Punch or Command Normal

- Kick (K) cancels into Dust (D) or Command Normal

- Close Slash (S) cancels into Slash, Heavy Slash (HS), Dust or Command Normal

- Slash cancels into Heavy Slash

    Besides that, there are the Roman Cancels and Bursts. Roman cancel is when you press 3 action buttons, besides Dust, and your character sends a shockwave that slows down the enemy for a few frames depending on the situation (which is indicated by the color of the Roman cancel: Blue, Yellow, Red and Purple), giving you tools to scape, trap or even extend combos. The burst is either a "get off me" tool to stop combos from enemies, or a more aggressive tool to gain meter faster when used at the right instant. All those mechanics are integrated in a fast-paced combat that gives room for smart play, quick thinking and originality. It is immensely satisfying to perform those mechanics and use them to your advantage, while maintaining your own fighting style.

It lacks Instant Kills, backdash has little invulnerability, airdash is clunky, stray hits do too much without followup, pressure is often strike/throw and high/low mixups are hard to come by for many characters without meter, wallbreak instead of traditional corner pressure, combos are often simple and/or boring and even a few hits into wallsplat into super does half health.

But most of all, it just manages to be less fun.  Pick your reason but it's just far far less fun.  I'd hope they could make each entry instead more fun.

Over a year into its life this game still has so many crippling issues that the developers seemingly just don't care about fixing. Updates come and go that make minor changes to one thing or another but never address the things people have been complaining about since release.

Half of the terminals for matches in lobbies just don't work, you walk up to them and just get an error message. Probably another half again of the terminals people manage to get onto won't accept opponents, they just give another error message. There's a semi-automated matchmaking system that will place you against people while you practice in training mode so you can sort of circumvent the barely functioning lobbies, but it's unable to handle people who go AFK in the queue or people you've declined matches or rematches with, so if you get matched against someone like that the system will just keep giving you the same exact prompt to play them over and over.

The ranked tower constantly interrupts you by limiting you to three matches against someone at a time, presumably to stop people from grinding easy rank off of someone, but doesn't stop you from just getting back on the terminal again against the same person after those three matches for three more. All it accomplishes is forcing you to sit through loading screens. Every few matches it will also stop you completely to inform you you're being moved to another floor so you never get any time to get to known people on any floor, defeating the purpose of a lobby system entirely. The whole system is also set up in such a way as to gradually shift the entire playerbase upwards in level, regardless of whether or not people are really getting better at the game, so eventually everyone will basically just be lumped together in one big pool where the skill disparity is comical. It's already happened for the top half of the playerbase and it's probably only going to be another couple months before it's happened to the bottom half as well.

EDIT: They finally added pre-match ping indicators in the second year of the game's lifespan, they take a good 10+ seconds to show up though and are frequently inaccurate, I've had many matches that showed a stable 40-80 ping green connection indicator before the match only to be horrible 8f rollback lagfests. But hey, at least the indicator is there now, useful or not that's a step in the right direction.

You'll also sometimes get disconnected mid-round for seemingly no reason, perfectly good matches stop abruptly mid attack with a minute long "please wait" message before you're kicked all the way back to the main menu. Sometimes it doesn't even get as far as letting you start the match and just gives the disconnect message as soon as you approach a terminal.
It's really embarrassing that people point to this as the fighting game with the best netcode, if a game in any other genre was released with these kinds of network issues it would be mocked ruthlessly.

The game has acquired a reputation for being a good entry point into the fighting game genre but it's vastly overblown, the tutorials are garbage for anything more than learning you can hold back to block and how to extend your combos but the real meat of learning the game is understanding what every character can do and the character-specific tutorials are awful and go no further than "hit the slow move before it finishes" or "jump over the projectile". They added a system for sharing combos with other players to help people learn offense but you can't load those combos into training mode to practice against, you have to manually record yourself doing the combos so if you're struggling to figure out how to deal with something you better hope you're able to do it yourself.

It's really a shame because from a strictly gameplay perspective it's an enjoyable game, but when you have to go through such a struggle just to get to the point of actually playing the game and it's fighting against every attempt you make to improve it's hard to feel like it's worth launching at all.

SEASON 3 UPDATE: They said in the patch notes that they'd fixed a lot of the issues with the lobbies. They lied, all the old issues are still present but on top of those now when you try to change between rooms you get a network error and get kicked back to the start screen and have to go through all the menus again to get back to the room you were trying to go to.
