As someone who has been somewhat familiar with this series for quite a long time, was really looking forward to this game a bunch, and initially liked it pretty well, the amount of complete mismanagement it's seen has completely lost my interest in it.
It still has qualities worth praise, the music and art direction is still godlike as you'd expect of the modern series, however, nearly every single other aspect of the game has become increasingly poorly managed post release, and is now at a breaking point for me.

The servers now barely work and have had severe issues for over a year yet despite online quality being one of the original big praises for the game andArcSys has done nothing to fix it, and online being in shambles since crossplay and entire regions being able to play the game since a year after release, the game consistently gets glitchier 
 
the gameplay shifts between overly simple/basic to overly complex/convoluted from character to character will little consistency, you have braindead simple characters with no depth like Sol going up against incomprehensible characters like Asuka and nearly most DLC characters have some unnecessary meter or resource even when it doesn't make sense, none of which feels cohesive.
 
They're completely destroying their characters by completely changing core aspects of their backstories and personalities and etc which is most egregiously on display with the trio of Faust/Testement/Bridget none of which have remote effort trying to explain such core drastic changes with Faust not even being remotely touched on for like 2 years+ despite being a mainstay and there being several movies

The monetisation of confusing and absurd, they charge the same amount for all season passes but they have very different amounts of content in them, and they charge an absurd amount for a DLC that only has one single additional color palate for the base roaster which even had a 2 year exclusivity period, and most colour and deluxe DLCs and such are heavily misleading and sneaky not giving as much as they imply, and there being content only available through season passes meaning you should never buy characters or etc individually.
And the price for the game and it's DLC fluctuate randomly to absurd degrees lowering and raising massive amounts in specific regions with no real pattern, with there recently being being a change that increases the price across the board from anywhere from 5% to a insane 90% with the countries receiving the 90% already having much more difficulty buying games whatsoever.

And the community has massively gone downhill after the initial year, with constant toxicity, attacks, flame-wars, aggression, strawmen, hate, bigotry, bootlicking, projection, elitism, generationalism, and etc completely unlike the rather likeable and chill and funny fandom the game temporarily had during most of the first year. And while there's many high quality costume mods and such people have made, there's a sizable amount of drama and bias and inequality and discourse surrounding most of that too.

Overall, as someone who put several hundred hours into this game initially and really liked it for a while, it's such a shame to see how it's had the ball dropped time and time again in most areas since, with music and art being the only consistently reliable aspect.
There are still things worth caring about the game, but overall it's become such a mess and I no longer recommend it or have intention to keep playing.
I suggest looking towards one of Arcsys's other games such as Xrd or X2 or DBFZ or any of the Blazblues except CrossTagBattle, maybe Persona arena.
Or maybe you'll prefer some of the other great Fighting Games coming out around now or on the horizon, Street Fighter 6 is fantastic though you'll have to prepare yourself for abysmal levels of monetisation if you set your sights on it.

Guilty Gear = Good; OST = Peak; Looks Like Anime.

If you already like +R or Rev2, this game probably isn't grimy enough for you. If you haven't played any other Guilty Gear before, that's probably what makes this the best game to get into the series with. There's still Big Damage and Flashy Combos, but with substantially less Anime Fighting Game Wackiness that leaves you wondering what your opponent even did to you. (If you want to do Anime Fighting Game Wackiness to other people, that's when you go to one of the older games)

Do I think this is a great fighting game? Yes, of course.
Do I love the characters and story? Absolutely.
Is this my favorite Guilty Gear game? No, but I support their efforts.
Am I happier when I don't play online? Yes.
Do I like fishing for items? Nope. Didn't like it in Xrd, either.

I'll probably edit or delete this later, but here's a rundown of the USD pricing (June 2021 ~ August 2023), because the new "Daredevil Edition" looks like a mess:

The initial release on Steam had Standard and Deluxe options, but no Ultimate Edition.
Standard = base game (15 characters) = $60
Deluxe = base game + season pass 1 = $85
Also, “GGST Special Colors for Sol and Ky” (the EX color swap for characters *and* effects) was a special freebie that was only redeemable for the first two weeks (in June 2021). I *think* they temporarily brought it back during season 2. Maybe. I need to double-check that.

So, SP1 was $25. SP2 was also $25. Now, SP3 is $25 as well. Consistency. Nice.
The base game price became $40 (August 2022). Yay for price drops.
25th Anniversary Appreciation Color DLC (May 2023) = free. Who doesn't like free?
FYI, the Necessary Discrepency OST (May 2022) = music through SP1.
All of that makes sense, right?

The "Ultimate Edition Content Kit," when Steam finally got it (thanks, probably-1-yr-contract-PS-exclusive color) should've been $15, max. More like $10. It is, however, $20. The PS4 and PS5 Ultimate Editions cost $100, which basically** added this "content kit" DLC to the Deluxe Edition ($85).
** PS4 and PS5 digital editions also had 3 days of *partial* early access back in June 2021. (The initial release of GGST wasn't exactly smooth.)

The new "Daredevil Edition" bundle info (Aug 2023) is confusing and horribly misleading. You're not saving $144, because it's counting DLC twice. It should be a savings of $43.
Base game = $40
SP1, 2, 3 = $75
Ultimate Edition Content Kit = $20 (again, should be much cheaper -- never on sale)
25th Anniversary Colors = $8 (should've been in SP2, let's be honest -- never on sale)
Total = $143, not $244.

-+-+-+-

My last point and biggest concern right now: there haven't been any story mode updates since SP1. I love the extra stories in GGXrd, which has three -- so far GGST only has one. I *need* more than arcade mode conversations and unique match quotes between *some* characters. I would be happy with the equivalent of a drama CD/radio drama, esp if it has the on-screen line-by-line replayable script option (I love that in story mode). Anything.

-- Horrible, horrible lobbies (we not even talking about visuals) 24 player room for ranked with average online ~3 thosand ppl. Yeah, thats about right, i always dreamed to play with the very same people all the time.
-- After YEAR devs acknowledged that we have some connection problems and idk if they ever fix it, but around 25% of the games just don't connect even with the same player you played before.
-- [strike] We still need to wait around 3 minutes[/strike] ("fixed" year later and now we need to waste around 1 minute to get online) to get online or download third party tools to speed it up. A lot of downtime - between matches, floor changes (evil when you try to get to celestial), long ending scene, overdrives ffs, you can get 50% tension faster than their animation, i want to play, not to watch something.
-- Balance... if you played previous games this is the same shit all over again, 2 balance patches in a year, plenty of broken chars barely get any nerfs yada-yada, asians can't balance, we all know it. At start we barely have any HP and after all the buffs almost all chars can kill in 2 combos, it's fun for comeback EVO moments or something, but not that fun in other cases. Besides when devs explained what strive strives to be - it was no corner lock, no wake up lock, no long combos with poke startup and year later it's sad to see, wake up lock is real, corner lock kinda not here, but when wall breaks it's already a loss of huge hp chunk and you usually die on second wall break and they ADDED poke CH's confirm last patch. Defensive tools using resource generated from offence, so attacking side have all advantages. (upd 2 years later. now burst gauge can be used in offence to confirm random midscreen pokes and steal burst from the opponent. And postivie bonus recovers it, so wallbreak snowballs even harder and at the start of the round chars have full burst, so easy confirms. Bravo. Why do we even have 99 seconds round time, should have probably cut it to 30.)
-- Ranking system is shit, you have 11 floors with more than 1/4 of the players on the last two and no one on 1-5. Then 11th floor is celestial and you need 5 wins out 6 games to get there, so with some luck almost anyone can get there (or get carried by someone, since you can't drop out) and with 24ppl in the instance SBMM basicaly doesn't work. Overall "skill level" is invisible (in fighting game btw) and if you don't use 3rd party sites you can't check it for yourself. So, basicaly, you have celestial, where around 15% of the players are and thats it, all ingame rankings is about how many matches you played there, best fighting game metric for sure.
-- Ping indicator ingame is great, but why we can't filter out ppl by it? Like 24 man lobby, there is 2-3 dudes with bad Wi-Fi/200+ms delay or bad internet/route and your auto battle option (no one in the right mind gonna do it manually) gonna challenge this same dude all over again, no matter if you or they press cancel all the time, do you know definition of insanity?
--Rollback connection is usually great, playable up to 200ms (if both sides have good internet) some predictions on high ping are broken like Anji overhead when you see low animation startup, rollback and you already got hit by overhead.
--And old problem if opponent have potato computer still there. You gonna be in lag hell together for some reason, but they are born and bred there, and you just a passerby. And on top of that - you can't leave match midgame, i would prefer this option. Take my lose and get out of this, but nope... alt+f4 works, but load time is so long, that for me it's easier to just turn off the game and play something else.

[strike] Core gamplay is kinda fine, greatly dumbed down to low health advanced version of SF5, you may hate it, you may like it. No decent ranking system and lobby, overall feels like it's still beta version of the game.[/strike] 
2 years later. I feel like game created and balanced for the middle of the pack players. If you one of them - try it, you will have a lot of fun, otherwise i don't advise it.

At first I didn't think I would like this game very much. I was neck deep in DBFZ and didn't feel like playing much else. But once I gave the game a chance I was thoroughly hooked. Its a perfect game for those who want to get into fighting games but are intimidated by giants of the genre like Street Fighter and Tekken. The inputs may have been simplified from the previous game but the game keeps a majority of its mechanical depth. Things like the Roman Cancel and gatling systems make the game very rewarding for newbies and veterans. Thats not even mentioning the visuals and soundtrack. I cannot stop listening to this OST, every time a character is released the first thing I want to hear is their theme. The visuals are also absolutely beautiful, all the animations are spot on and very pleasing to watch. In conclusion...

update: with recent season changes i'm no longer certain this review applies. but theres still some tid-bits that still may apply.
The recent new mechanics such as wild assault has drastically increased the speed and possibilities for interactions giving a lot more varity to individual playstyles and decision making. Uncertain of the future the mechanic will have on higher level play but for now it's a good tool for getting genuine interactions and just being able to get in more often.

tl;dr: fighting games are a wild world of spending way to many hours investing to see where things head in a longer term, often or not this takes a direction that majority of players don't exactly enjoy.
However because of the high invest time the ability to refund gets taken away from you pre-maturely once you've reached that point where you fully understand that you just don't like the interactions the game's meta has evolved around. It becomes quite easy to feel like your time and investment has been robbed from you. I don't feel like getting better at this game was worth it as the challenges of the game aren't enjoyable.

Review below is pretty opinionated take on the interactions as personally i enjoy more fast pace decision heavy gameplay with a continuely growing tech finese scale (games like tf2/quake personally fill this role quite well as the more you learn and adjust to the game mechanics the more options open up over time and the more you can do)
Seeing as i haven't gotten deep into fighting games until strive (only slightly dabling in older titles) i always wanted to learn them, after playing strive and branching out to a few other fighting games i've come to the realisation that the way high level gameplay evolves almost universally in these games is in an inverted sort of funnel where overtime options and decisions get narrowed down rather then opened up, you don't make more decisions and perform more hard executions, you just get more autopiloted routes that are designed to cover other routes and you end up making smaller decisions that lead into those routes.
The reason to do this is to lower the amount of things you need to hon/focus on, so things that are overly general will win out against things that are very specific.
This results in games that don't feel like your playing against a real player but instead games where you are either playing against a sandbag that your just dunking on, or your filling the role of the sandbag as the interaction has been taken from you.
This leads to a very unenjoyable experience and it's an experience that is unfortunetly really common in the genre, games like these drop off hard because at the end of the day they just aren't fun for extended periods of time. 

Mainly because Winning isn't fun, and losing isn't educational.
After understanding the game, you don't learn anything. You just make a lot of guesses in an RPS system with a lot of option selects.

Personally, this game isn't for me. As the slow pace and direction arcsys has been pushing by adding so many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ zoners to the game has made the rushdown playstyle i enjoyed at the start of the game, nearly impossible to enjoy at a high level now.
The only times i'll be able to rush down an opponet is when their a fresh install and that just doesn't make me feel good as i unlike most iwho play this game, i happen to have a moral conscious and i don't like playing against people who can't compete when i know for a fact that what i did was straight up unsafe and wouldn't work in a real match.
If you're like me, then just play something else (like tf2), avoid fighting games, they are all snake oil at the core.

I really really wish i could get that time i spent back, i feel like arcsys should've been paying me to play this ♥♥♥♥, not the other way around.
These games fall off hard for a reason, people in positions within FGC may not want to state it aloud because they rely on these games, but it's something that i'm certain everyone secretly knows as a major flaw with these games they just don't want to admit it and companies like arcsys have monetary incentive to make sure the flaw doesn't get fixed (how else can they sell more games and hype culture to funnel people into tournments under the thinly veiled promise of glory.

In many ways the genre hasn't left it's arcade routes of scamming quarters from kids, they just do it to even bigger kids now.

This game is great for newcomers, despite the bit of controversy on mechanical changes from previous games in my experience. Aside from having the best visuals in any fighting game to date and an amazing soundtrack, I've been able to get several people into this game who had no interest in other ArcSystemWorks games because of the accessibility barrier being lowered. They even feel the motivation to actually go into training mode and lab out their characters, which is very rare for casual players to do in my experience. 

Overall this is a great game with good accessibility and outstanding online, and the high sales so far mean it's likely to be supported by ArcSys for a long time. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys fighting games, casual or otherwise. 

The only real issues are that the online lobbies, especially on PC, are often difficult to get matches in due to how inconsistently matches go through, with player lobbies with specific ID codes being unusable at the time this review was written, though I expect that will change. Once you're in a match, though, the game has the smoothest online experience of any online fighting game I've played. (I forgot to change this when it happened, but player lobbies are usable now. The game does still have a few bugs in the lobby system, though.)

Season 3 Edit: This game got some new mechanics that fucking rule, and the online still isn't 100% ideal but it's improved enough that I've never had any issues.

From a person who plays GG since the very first one, I thought the simplification of the game mechanics would r.i.p. the game.

"Here we go again. Another game ruined by 'gamer journalists' who can't press 2 buttons at the same time" - I said.

BUT after spending some time in practice and rocking in some online matches, for my surprise, they didn't kill the mechanics at all! Arc System really simplified the game up to a level where casual players can enjoy the game too! They didn't lie! It's a fucking Christmas miracle! Hooray!

Yeah, I know, they bend the knee a tiny little bit to the cancel-culture-kiddo-weirdos. The female costumes are not as hot as they used to be (I miss I-No's naked boombas too), but hey, at least the didn't nerf the mechanics down to a "gamer journalist" level.

To me, that's a 75% win.

Guilty Gear Strive is one of the best fighting games of all time from a pure visual standpoint alone. Even if the gameplay sucked, I would still love the visuals. The transitions from cutscenes to gameplay are seamless, and never interrupt the intensity of a match. The soundtrack is incredible two. The story mode not being playable makes sense, and it's there for the fans and serves as a great conclusion to the 20 year long running story. Still, I really wish it was playable... and that Jack-O was base roster cause like. Come on. In this context, it's like making Chun-Li DLC.

Maintaining a wide audience has always been a challenge for fighting games. The core of the genre is usually only experienced by the minority that the genre caters to. The experience you have is entirely dependent on how you enjoy the genre, making it difficult to create a general review that potential players can use to gauge their decision on purchasing GUILTY GEAR -STRIVE-. I will be reviewing the game based off how I personally enjoy fighting games.

I found GGST most fun as a game to learn how to play, climb up ranked to a point I was satisfied with, and only revisit to occasionally fight versus friends or complete achievements. My enjoyment came from mastering game knowledge to participate in competition. I know very little about the single-player content it provides, but that is a result of how I chose to play GGST.

Learning how to play is easy with the amount of resources GGST provides combined with external resources to arrive at what makes fighting games fun faster than most games of its genre. The series has done an excellent job in simplifying mechanics of its past installments while still having creative applications to make combat fun. GGST runs online matches entirely on rollback netcode, making each match feel smooth despite distance or connection. Another great feature of GGST lies in its gorgeous visuals. Arc System Works are the golden standard for anime-style games, GGST being no exception to that fact.

However, the game's skill floor has increased over time as it does with most fighting games making its initial learning curve more difficult. If this will affect your enjoyment of the game, I would recommend playing more recent fighting game releases. GGST also has issues with balancing certain characters and controversially being too simple to control. This reduces the consistency of veteran players and its understandable to be upset when mastery isn't rewarded as much to those who commit themselves to the game the most.

GGST succeeds in welcoming new players to an intimidating genre. It's a great starting point for someone looking to introduce themselves to the anime fighting game genre as it is one of the most beginner-friendly fighting games on the market. If you can see yourself getting behind its flaws and appreciating the best of what GGST has to offer, I would recommend trying it out yourself.

Strive is beautiful, the music kicks ass, and the netcode is phenomenal. Unfortunately, it hasn't fixed a lot of issues that were present in Xrd, and made some worse.

The ranked system is bizarre, rooms are their own weird 2d platformer and have no built-in player rotation, Steam integration doesn't work, and the best option for joining friends is sharing 6 character room codes.

The DLC characters have much less intuitive counterplay than the base roster, and also cannot be used in training mode without buying the DLC.

Subjectively, I'm also not a big fan of the differences from Xrd. The game was made slower and longer combos were removed, but some of the aspects of Xrd that made it accessible (like the universal gatling combo) were also removed, which I think hurts both competitive and casual play.

This is a pretty good game but it's absolutely the weakest of the main three that are commonly played, Plus R, Xrd, and Strive. Mechanics such as FRC/YRC and IKs are no longer there, movesets for characters have been heavily simplified and cut entirely, poor Faust and Bedman, the wall breaking mechanic makes a lot of corner combos feel worse since it'll just reset neutral anyways, music is decent but doesn't reach the highs of the other soundtracks, lack of iconic characters such as Venom, Dizzy, Jam, and Slayer really sucks, and the visuals while good are nowhere near as appealing as Xrd's cell shading or Plus R's spritework. Good game for beginners as well as it's very easy to pick up but there's not a lot to master at all and it doesn't actively feel rewarding to master either. I enjoy playing this with friends a lot it's a fun game but Plus R and Xrd deliver a better Guilty Gear experience

Guilty Gear Strive is an amazing game. Its the fighting game that got me into the genre, and im thankful that it did. The gameplay rocks, the music rocks, and the visuals are unmatched. Each character is unique and plays vastly differently from any other given character. Its pretty much impossible to not find a character that you like to play. Each track from this game has stayed in my playlist for the past couple of years and i find something new to appreciate with them pretty often. Another thing that i love about this game is the community and FGC as a whole. Because of this game I got to meet a lot of really cool people in the wider FGC space. And I gotta say playing at locals is some of the most fun ive had in a while. Sure the game is a bit unbalanced, and we're currently in a bit of a lull of content, but the game is still great and is fun to play. The online is great when it works, but getting into a match can still be somewhat  troublesome. Overall, guilty gear strive is absolutely worth your time. And so, I found myself standing before the fiery gates of hell. Just behind it a gaping crater, so infinite in size that it consumed everything around it. As if I was falling into a black hole, the crater stretched and contorted to gobble everything in every direction. There was no horizon. There was no sky. Only the gates, burning eternally. I turned around to see a small light behind me. Beyond was mortality, a gateway back to the life I had once lived. Should I go through it, I could return once more to the world I once knew, live a little bit longer, do the things I never did, live a life just a bit more fulfilled. But that would never happen. There was no second chance, no cheap trick. The light was but another trick of the realm to torment those few souls with just a bit of hope left. No one would ever reach the light, for it lie at the end of the crater's infinitely far edge. To try and cling on to hope and make the infinite trek back was just another punishment of eternal suffering. I turned back to the gates and walked forward. As I went through them, the light behind me vanished. Past the gates, stood the devil himself. He stood still and patiently, as if he had been waiting for me since the day I was born. He beckoned for me to come closer, and said, "Welcome to your eternal damnation. There is no nine rings of fire for you here as your punishment, just like that of every other unfortunate soul to come here, is that of emptiness. To wander the endless void, devoid of all hope, to let your mind go numb, to have your very being rot and fester until there is no more left of you to corrupt. This is your last interaction for after I leave you on your way, you will have nothing, no one to speak to, no surface to feel, no sounds to hear, no light to see, no aroma to smell, no food to taste. It will just be you and your thoughts. And when your thought runs out and your mind burns up, there will be nothing left but the silence echoing through your consciousness. You will rot and decay until you are nothing more than the emptiness that surrounds you." He looked at me, expecting me to say something to him. But I said nothing, only looking on to the void that would soon become my one and only eternal companion. But then, something came to me. It grew in my stomach, spreading to my lungs and diaphragm. It crawled up my throat and flooded my mouth. It kicked at my lips, shattering my teeth just to get out. My muscles moved on their own, acting out of their own volition, freed of my control. My head moved up, my eyes met his. And as he looked at me, peering into my deepest thoughts, the thing finally escaped, bursting from of my mouth, flying out in every direction. His eyes widened in disbelief and his mouth grew to an amused smile as I said something that no one had ever said to him before. 
"236236S."

This game makes it hard for you to even play the game if you want to. The issue with the game is that it continues to struggle helping me find people to play against even with its active player base. The game has been out for years and its match finding has never been updated. The game has NO matchmaking. You have to enter into a lobby and find players to play with manually. Then, there are problems with connecting to other players, and there are players with high ping in your region because they are connecting from a different country since everyone joins a select couple servers. As a result, it takes you a long time to find a good game. 

You can find a game faster if you want to play ranked at a specific rank, because most players are connecting to the higher ranked lobbies, which the game lets you access at any time regardless of your current rank. Therefore, the ranked system also lacks skill based matching, so new players will have a really hard time learning how to play. Particularly because the gameplay loop of going from a match to training mode and back takes longer than even Tekken 7, a 5 year older game, simply because this game will not do matchmaking. You have to load into training mode, select characters, exit, go to online, wait for it to load an connect to server, find a populated lobby, find a player in that lobby to play with, all this could take 5 minutes each time or more. The only thing assisting new players is the community's amazing resources for this series. 

The game has a "quick match" option but this is not matchmaking, it simply puts you into a ranked lobby, with no choice of entering a casual lobby, and you sit in training mode until a person joins your lobby and walks up to your character in the lobby and selects 'play' on you. Not to mention they can see what character you are playing, which can making it so some players get more matches than others due to game balance and character popularity. This game makes it hard for you to even play the game if you want to. It says I have almost 200 hours played in this game, but how much of that time is spent finding a match and loading between menus? It would be longer than you think, the longest of any of the top fighting games available. Just play SF6

I moved to to this version of GG after a lot of research. My intro to FGs was SFIV. I like SF but it is extremely unforgiving in terms of executions and even the rhythm during long input moves is not consistent, you might switch up the tempo right in the middle of the execution. So far, GGS has been really fun and more forgiving while also making a real effort to help new players understand setups. how and when to cancel, and how/when to combo, understanding these things can transfer between fighting games.
I am glad I bought it and am excited to keep playing and learning.

Throwaway since my BF knows my Reddit account. One evening, me (F22) and my boyfriend (M21) were watching memes on YouTube from his phone, something we frequently do together. He REALLY likes memes and quotes them often throughout the day, no matter whether he is happy or being goofy and even when he is raging at a game or genuinely heartbroken. One day about a year ago, he came home to tell me he got fired and said "my life be like oooh aaah". It's probably a coping mechanism for him, but personally I do not understand it.

Anyways, we saw one meme, a guy a clearly masturbating saying things "I'm about to cum" but it was spelt out as "ambatukam", and thought it was the funniest thing ever so we looked for more. There were more videos of him being edited into scenarios like him mourning the loss of his brother named "Bato Khan", and we spent no less than 20 minutes laughing nonstop at these videos. Afterwards when we went to make dinner, my BF said joking "that's what I'm gonna say in bed now".

Fast forward a day later, both of us are horny and head to the bedroom to fuck. It was great, but then towards the end, my BF said loudly "ambatukaaaam" and then proceeded to cum. I laughed along with him but I was a little uncomfortable because it sorta killed the vibe.

About a week later, we're having sex again, and he says them same exact thing as last time, but this time, he laughs "just kidding, I'll stop" afterwards. Well, it turns out he wasn't really telling the truth because the next time we had sex, he said "bouttobus". I then whining-ly said his name in desperation and he then chuckled.

We didn't have sex for about a month until last night. We were doing fine as usual, and he even managed to cum without saying any memes... or so I thought, because right afterwards, he said something along the lines of "thank you for letting me buss, it's what I needed". I can't even remember much of what happened during or after that because I was in pure shock that we would just kill the vibe like that again. All I remember is that we cleaned up and he went to play COD or something that involved him shouting stupid jokes and memes to his friends.

I do not have the heart to tell him that he isn't funny when he does this, because the last time I confronted him when he kept saying "yooo that's sus" every time I mentioned something vaguely sexual, he almost cried. He stopped saying that one phrase but still has about a thousand other memes in his vocabulary. I guess this is just my life now, and as much as I want it to stop, I love my boyfriend so much and will have to live with it.

Guilty Gear Strive is my favorite fighting game. 
It is a fantastic franchise, with a colorful and unique history, with every character being an incredible explosion of personality and care. The lore is rich, but never the true focus. In the series latest entry, characters and mechanics were streamlined, with many of the more complicated actions much simpler. At first I really didn’t like this change, but I’ve grown to appreciate what makes it different from the other games in the series. In fact, I’ve grown to appreciate every inch of this game. The more I played, the more I liked it. Even though things seem simple, a world of depth is revealed within it all. 
The characters breathe creativity and experimentation. It feels like you’re diving into a cave of options with every choice you have. Despite its small roster, it makes up for it in spades with originality and profound expression. The more I played, the more I understood. Everything in this game just feels right. Creating your own custom combos has never been easier or more enjoyable. I have to give a shoutout to the ‘Combo Recipe’ feature, which lets me save and load my own combos to practice in training mode. Within minutes I’m able to set a large amount of fun combos to try, all made by me. It’s wonderful, and It’s such a shame more fighting games don’t have this. 
The music is incredible, as with all the Guilty Gear games. Each theme is tremendous in it’s layers of meaning and powerful tones. They are all full length songs, with amazing lyrics and wondrous melodies. 
The game is gorgeous. It has to be the most beautiful game I’ve ever played. When I saw footage, I knew I had to play it. Each stage has so much care and effort put into it it destroys the competition. I adore the stages. With so much detail and such amazing art direction, it really feels like you’re in a new location seeing the events fold out for yourself. 
The online is smooth and reliable, with no issues there. 
The story mode is ok, but I see it as a general step down from Xrd. 
Arcade mode is fun, with some great surprises in there. 
And of course, I can’t not mention the incredible representation. I never thought I would be seen so well by a fighting game, but here we are. Bridget is a miracle I never thought would happen, but she is real, and she is amazing. Every word she spoke felt like it was coming out of my own mouth. Daisuke has taken a massive risk, but it means more to me and other players more than he may ever know. I am incredibly, incredibly grateful for his vision and amazing compassion. It’s clear to me what this game is trying to say, and it’s something so very special. 
This game, this franchise, and this story is dear to me, and has gone beyond and above what I ever imagined. To Daisuke and the rest of the team, thank you for making such an astoundingly good experience, and for showing the world what happens when you don’t back down. 
This game will keep on blazing until the end of time. Thank you. 
Thank you so much. <3 <3 <3

[h1]Learning to Love Guilty Gear Strive in 2023[/h1]

Guilty Gear Strive steadily approaches its 3rd year of service. Guilty Gear Strive is probably the best example of a game released at the right time in the right place. With all other major Fighting Games slowly winding down and getting ready for the generational leap, ArcSystems swooped in and released what might be their best title yet. The new Guilty Gear looks amazing, plays fantastically, and is easy to grasp for players. Add to that a soundtrack that slaps harder than a fullscreen combo and you have yourself the fighting game that mainevented EVO in 2022.

[b]But with a new Street Fighter releasing and Tekken right around the corner, how does the most stylish fighting game stack up in 2023?[/b]

[h1]The Smell of the Game[/h1]

Talking about fighting games is always difficult because eventually, every newcomer will run into an impossible information brick wall. Frame data, 15-hit combos, and all those characters that have their own quirks to work out and react to. It's too much of a mountain to climb before you even get to a point where all of this makes sense to you. And just like Dragon Ball FighterZ, Strive tries to lower the barrier to entry by making all those concepts a little more digestible. But unlike Dragon Ball FighterZ, you now have options now that lower the frustrations of getting your ass beaten. It's still not perfect by any means, but Guilty Gear Strive is relatively easy in execution. And once you learn a few combo setups and how to punish, you can focus more on honing your craft without getting absolutely destroyed. All of this is just a longwinded way of saying, Guilty Gear Strive is a great game if you want to get into fighting games but offers enough for veterans to stick around. Especially since it foregoes the usual trappings of the anime-fighter subgenre. Characters with mechanics and gimmicks are so complex, a degree and extended training course are required to get a baseline understanding.

[h1]Love the Subhuman Self[/h1]

The amount of content in Strive is absolutely insane. After all, it is a love letter to the long-running series and feels very much like the grand finale for most of its characters. There is a story mode, which is more or less two seasons worth of anime rendered in ArcSystem's beautiful art style that you can watch at your own convenience. And you don't even have to fight in between major story beats. And if you're not familiar with the Guilty Gear franchise, don't worry. Strive comes with an exhausting glossary that includes the history of the entire franchise since its inception in 1998. An excellent training mode that comes with all the bells and whistle's you want in a fighting game, minus the actual frame data. And expensive list of missions that in egregious detail explain everything you need to know about the gameplay. Even how to handle certain characters and their super annoying abilities, so you can spend more time practicing what you need to practice instead of trying to figure out what you did wrong in the first place. A great addition is also the combo lab. Here you can practice and save your own combos and upload them to the games server. You can also download other peoples combo's for each specific character to practice in a self-made mission mode. As for ranked play and online play, Guilty Gear Strive really loves to shove people into its various lobbies. You can create and decorate your own, or attempt to climb the tower. It's not perfect by any means and as of writing, playing online and matching up with other players can be a little rough. But the matchmaking itself does a great job of putting you up against players of your skill level. So generally, Guilty Gear is bursting with combat if you're here for cutscenes and or online play. For singleplayer there is your bog standard Arcade mode. But outside of a number of bot fights with some little voiced cutscenes in between, it'll get dull really fast.

[h1]Find Your One Way[/h1]

Guilty Gear Strive features a diverse roster of characters that only expands as the game's lifecycle progresses. And there is enough variety here to please even the hardest of critics. I mean who doesn't want to play an artificial doomsday device with two gigantic swords or the world's most excitable, buff 5-year-old? Characters in Strive ooze charisma, be it unique voice lines and animations depending on who they're up against. And that doesn't even scratch the surface, especially with those bangers they call their theme songs. Guilty Gear has always been a love letter to Rock n' Roll but Strive's soundtrack takes it to another level. Just look up the 1-year anniversary music video they showed at EVO last year. Mechanically, they all distinguish themselves from each other. Every single character still offers that signature Guilty Gear depth while also being relatively easy to pick up. Be it Ky Kiske's take on the Shoto-Archetype (He has a Sword) or Bridget's Yo-yo that makes for an excellent tool for spacing and lets her pressure across long distances. It's really hard to recommend anyone since all the characters promote their own playstyle, and with the Roman Cancel's the possibilities for combos and big brain plays seem endless.

[b]The best way to pick a character is probably just taking whoever you fancy into the dojo and messing around with them. Get a really good feeling for their individual attacks and practice their special moves.[/b]

[h1]What Do You Fight For[/h1]

If you want to get into fighting games or are just looking for something to cut your teeth at before Tekken 8 roll around. Guilty Gear Strive is probably the best fighting game to pick up right now. The community is still extremely active with a very healthy competitive scene so it won't be hard to find people to play and practice with. If you're coming in with no experience in 2D fighting games, Guilty Gear Strive is probably one of the most accessible ones out there (SFVI is a good option too). You'll spend more time learning and honing your basics instead of trying to hit extremely dodgy multihit combo's that'll send your opponent across space and time. With a fantastic roster of characters, plenty of support from the developers, and extensive effort put into the tutorial. So if you're looking for a game you can play for hundreds if not thousands of hours, only to get stomped at your local tournament in pools. There are worse options out there and at least you're playing the most stylish Rock Opera in Gaming.

This game got me into the fighting game genre and it was the best entry for someone like me who had tried to get into fighting games but said games were MK11 or UFC 3 (If you can even count that) and those never really gripped to me strongly since they were both annoying. I was yelled at by friends to try the free beta and I absolutely loved it!

Personal story aside, this game is really fun and smooth! The controls are easy to learn and pretty responsive. The game is incredibly fast paced and matches can be 30 seconds long. The music is amazing and definitely a contender for my #1 favorite OST. The tower system is kinda annoying but it's fine. If you are someone playing a fighting game for the first time this game is pretty forgiving with inputs. You can easily do the inputs and they're easy to learn and master. Getting the hang of all the different systems, inputs, bursts, roman cancels, and supers is what really makes it all fun. It's easy to get into and there's a lot to learn. Highly recommend for a first timer.

This game is really great. That comes from somebody who usually doesn't LOVE fighting games. 

This is truly something that anybody can pick up and understand, but only those who actually take time to learn will be really exceptional. I'm not amazing at it, but can still say with confidence that everything from basic buttons to considerably complicated combos all make sense and feel satisfying. 

I haven't yet mentioned the soundtrack, and let me tell you, it's truly amazing and diverse. It contains everything from grandiose heroic anthems, to funky beats, to haunting, ghastly music. It's all there and it all fits.

TL;DR: The game is something special and I believe it's worthy of a try no matter if you usually play similar games, or not.

Great fighting game with deep mechanics, mostly amazing music and good character design. I still suck but that's to be expected.

The good:
• [b]The art style.[/b] Everything looks good and consistent.
• [b]The music.[/b] Most of it is heavy metal bangers with influences from other genres. Very memorable.
• [b]The combat mechanics.[/b] Unlike some fighting games I've seen this one doesn't massively overemphasise flashy cinematic super attacks and it's much more about fundamentals, timing, spacing... you know, the good stuff.
• [b]The combat balance, for the most part.[/b] Some characters are objectively stronger (=easier) but not overwhelmingly.
• [b]The netcode.[/b] The way the game handles latency is fairly smart and results in a smooth experience most of the time, provided you don't play with someone 5000 miles away.

The meh:
• [b]A fishing minigame...[/b] really? why do so many games have one of these?
• [b]The singleplayer content.[/b] There isn't much of it, this is clearly a PvP game first and foremost.

The bad:
• [b]The anime.[/b] Yes, the game contains a full-fledged anime and it's bad.
• [b]The netcode.[/b] Yes, I listed this under good but there's also the fact you can get randomly disconnected without warning or explanation, matching with an opponent can fail in like 10 unique ways and the devs' attempts to fix this haven't been very successful so far.

Every character has their own positive and negatives, and the game is well balanced, mostly. Competitive scene is growing bit by bit since this series blew up in popularity. All in all, the game is easily worth $30 USD. With another season pass of DLC characters coming soon, it's definitely worth picking up.

Guilty Gear Strive is a beautifully animated and very fun fighting game. It's relatively easy to pick up for newcomers yet still provides very deep gameplay mechanics. Plus, the soundtrack is fire. The online mode is decent, and I've never had any issues with it personally, but I have heard a good amount of folks complain about the servers not working. But, in my experience, it works great most of the time, and the netcode is solid. I definitely recommend this game if you've never played fighting games before, enjoy anime fighters, or just enjoy playing as a variety of weird and crazy characters.

An Ode to Potemkin 

Thank you Daisuke for your vision
Of our faithful armored clown.
A grappler god crafted with precision
To give our enemies a smack down.

Though he may lack super speed,
He makes it up with his heart.
A powerful man he is indeed,
His command grab is a work of art.

A hero to the common man,
From humble origins he began.
Born a slave and fought to be free,
A solider who fights for thee.

All the strength that he can muster
Is put in to every potemkin buster.
Rejoice in his muscle's power!
For it let's us climb the tower.

Fantastic fighting game. It's my first entry into the guilty gear franchise and I love it. The mechanics are slightly different from other fighting games, in that combos are often "discovered" as opposed to simply stringing together 4 buttons and seeing which ones work well. It is much more about timing and much more unforgiving if you mess up a combo.

That being said, the controls themselves are not too difficult to understand. The special moves for characters I would say are easier to pull off than other franchises, such as Mortal Kombat or Street Fighter.

The character design is odd, but usually to it's strength. It's takes a second to appreciate what they are going for if you're not used to seeing tons of sexy characters, such as Roided up badasses and half-dressed Femm-Fatales.

solid 8/10

From the repetitive of a semi-causal player, I both love and hate this game. Now, why do I hate this game? The game balance and the ranked tower. Characters are clearly unbalanced (ex. Sol's 5K, which is THREE FUCKING FRAMES) and it gets really annoying when everyone hops on that stuff. Then there's the rank tower. Where do I get started with that. Sure, it works, but it sucks when you get to examining it. One game, you may steamroll your opponent, next, you get absolutely wreaked. It would have worked better if it was ELO based, but it doesn't, and it sucks. But I think the positives outweigh the negatives. The gameplay is actually super enjoyable with character's that specialize in one thing really good and the netcode is stable at long ranges (from my experiences with connections from the United States and India). I say this game is a mixed bag at least, but it's enjoyable for the most part.

Review:

It's a great game, the best fighting game I've played in years. The characters are well-designed and when you invest time in a character, you can unlock their full potential and experience the peak of competition.

As someone who has been playing competitive games for years and has a passion for fighting games, I was able to reach the maximum rank within 24 hours. This game is definitely geared towards competitive play, and while some balancing and macro issues may arise from time to time, I thoroughly enjoyed the competition.

The music, modernized versions of old cult characters, and combo chains all contributed to my enjoyment of the game. It's no surprise that this game won the award for Best Fighting Game.

The story is well-handled for a fighting game and the skins are decent, although I think better skins could have been created beyond just color packs.

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys fighting games. I haven't played a game this much in a long time, my fingers were sore from gripping the controller so tightly.

Guilty Gear Strive absolutely rocks.

This is one of the best looking, best playing, best sounding games I can remember. It's an incredible introduction to fighting games and is bursting with tool to improve your game. With rollback and crossplay it's really easy and fast to get matches too, and their matchmaking system is super smart - it recommends a level for you to play at to find matches with comparably skilled players, but it doesn't prevent you from "playing up" into higher skill levels, it only prevents you from "playing down" to pub stomp new players. And all of that is just in the "tower" - the game's equivalent of ranked. There's plenty of casual matches to be had in the "park" as well.

If you've always been curious about the series or fighting games more broadly and think the game looks cool, pick it up. It is. Maybe the coolest.

If you are a new fighting game player looking for an ideal game to start with, this is for you. While teaching you many of Guilty Gear’s trademark mechanics, it will also teach you many of the fighting game basics and does so with well executed tutorial missions. The character diversity in this game is something that is also worth discussing, as there aren’t really any two characters (besides maybe Ky and Sol) that play similarly to each other. There is something for everyone here. You got your standard shotos, rushdown, grappler, zoner, technical, and much more. This game single handedly reinvigorated my passion for fighting games. I recommend it to anyone trying to get into fighting games or anyone who is a fan of anime fighting games in general.

Like a shiny coat of paint on a broken toy. Mechanics overall dumbed down for noncommittal newcomers. Gatlings are nonexistent and combos are brain dead easy (for the most part). Combine that with the extremely wack damage, 2 or 3 interactions and you're dead or win. Feels like 2D Tekken 7. The new wall mechanic is honestly really stupid and feels like it belongs to another series. Xrd had crazy mechanics sometimes but it lended a real identity and insane depth to characters. Strive cuts it all in half for the sake of accessibility. Many fighting games are doing this and that's fine if done correctly. Even Street Fighter 6 does this... kind of.

Street Fighter 6 came out a minute ago and it is the most accessible fighting game I've ever played. The option for Modern controls makes everything easier for newcomers and for some characters it's arguably broken. It's slower than previous games, interactions are extremely visually readable, most of the roster is extremely simple (not JP lol), etc. But that's not all it does. Certain V-Skills or moves from Street Fighter 5 became part of the core moveset for some characters in 6. This means characters have what they previously had and then some. This on top of the new Drive Gauge and it becomes a crazy deep game that can be as complicated as you want it to be. The roster all plays extremely different and have unique ways to approach them, as deep or as surface level as you feel comfortable with.

Strive misunderstood that depth means difficult and difficult is bad. Long story short, go play SF6 instead. Ryu gang.

I NEED TO SAY SOMETHING EXTREMELY IMPORTANT SO PLEASE LISTEN. THIS GAME IS GODLY AND ITS SUPER EASY TO GET INTO! WISH YOU DIDN'T SUCK AT FIGHTING GAMES? DON'T WORRY STRIVE HAS GOT YOU! DON'T EVEN LIKE 2D FIGHTING GAMES? FORGET ALL ABOUT THAT BECAUSE ITS SO EASY AND DIFFERENT! ITS EASY TO LEARN, HARD TO MASTER, AND YOU WILL LIKELY GET GOOD AND UNDERSTAND IN UNDER 20 HOURS!

Guilty Gear Strive is a godly and super fresh breath of fresh air for 2D fighting games. Its truly like no other with a character for everyone that plays so differently it almost completely changes the game! Not only are things easier to pull off in game play but commands are easy to learn and slide into, along side a great tutorial to do so. You will jump in to multiplayer and get rekt, but after awhile you will understand what you did wrong and grow, as you test and learn your characters you will become so much more. This is generally how fighting games work but for the record I'd like to state as someone who sucks at 2D fighting games this game has absolutely picked me up and taught me how! Its easy to get into and its so so FUN! There is an amazing online system with rollback net code that makes online matches feel as smooth as butter! I haven't experienced one single lag problem and felt like I was fighting someone in the same room! The tower and hub worlds are super cool and great ways to find matches nice an quick. As well as being able to customize your character with unlockables you can fish out which was pretty cool (very whatever but also very cool) and many ways to customize your profile too its all pretty cool. The game is simply just amazing, if you DON'T LIKE 2D fighting games AT ALL I STILL HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!

Great game, fun game, beautiful visual graphic and impressively done original sound track for each character. The gameplay is a like a 7 for me this game is good but the gameplay is kinda a lil off compared to the older games of the same franchise like GG Xrd REV 2 well like in the older games you can do much more than what you can in Strive example continuously combo on walls and stuff but that will be cancelled off by wallbreak in Strive which I understand that it's made to keep the balance and also gives the chance for the opponent to strike back at you but at the same time that could throw off the person who did their best to get them into corner. One of the most stylish games out there, Guilty Gear Strive is likely one of the best games to start your FGC experience.

PROS:
+ The game has the best music of nearly any game I've played before
+ All of the animations, characters, and stages are Beautiful
+ Easy (in terms of FGC) to learn, with lots of new player teaching tools, and has a decently high skill ceiling
+ The Rollback netcode is buttery smooth
+ active, friendly community
+ Continuing support from devs (character pass 3 incoming! ABA when?)
+ (unofficial) mods are available to modify music/sounds/colors/costumes to personalize your experience

CONS:
- The ranked mode/tower system and no seperate ranks for characters
- Lackluster single player/offline content
- Missing training mode features (frame data, hitboxes, advantage on block, etc.) Use the website dustloop to find any of this information

[b] [u] HEAVEN OR HELL? [/u] [/b]

Guilty Gear Strive is a fighting game masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of the genre. With its stunning visuals, intense gameplay, and deep mechanics, it delivers an adrenaline-fueled experience that will captivate both newcomers and fighting game veterans alike. The roster of diverse and well-designed characters offers a wealth of playstyles and strategies, ensuring endless hours of thrilling battles. The attention to detail in animations, stages, and sound design creates an immersive world that feels alive. Guilty Gear Strive is a must-play for fans of the genre, delivering an exhilarating and unforgettable fighting game experience!

2023-03-10: It's pretty fun when everything is working but the servers haven't been working for a few days now and there's been no updates... Let this be a warning of what to expect for anyone looking at this on sale during the Arc World Tour 2023. Some issues from launch took a year to be resolved. Latest security fix to stop anyone from being able to chat as you or crash your game seems to have broken everything else. Since they probably aren't going to roll that back I'm not expecting a quick fix.

It takes a long time to get good enough to know just how bad you are at this game and this one has been made easier to learn than the others. I played for a few months around launch, came back when Bridget came out and she's kept me here since.

I'll be giving some other Guilty Gear games a shot at some point but unless this one recovers soon this could be the end of my routine and I may end up with a different routine by then.

Update 2023-06-01: It's been nearly 3 months since a patch messed things up and a new patch on May 25 was supposed to fix everything but doesn't seem to have. Street Fighter 6 comes out tomorrow and it looks really good. Sadly this will probably be the end of online play for Strive. Even if they fix it later no one will be playing anymore. Sad times.

This game is great. 

+ Online play is smooth with very high-quality **rollback netcode**
+ Functional Crossplay between Steam, Windows, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S.
+ Every character is very unique, with many archetypes being represented
+ It is more accessible so it won't feel overwhelming to learn
+ Amazing visuals
+ Amazing rock soundtrack with vocal character themes
+ Great tutorial in the form of Mission Mode
+ Fun and intuitive system mechanics that complement each other

However, there are a few cons you should be aware of
 - Sparce single player content
 - Game needs to take time to connect to network upon startup for online play instead of a connect to network function in 
     the main menu similar to Blazblue Central Fiction. This usually last for a little while, though Arcsys has addressed the issue and hopefully will continue to do so.
 - Lobbies are difficult to navigate in Online Match. Player Match is more easier to connect to opponents and seems less 
     bugged

Even though these issues are present and definitely of valid concern, I'd more than recommend this game to anyone wanting to try out a fun and rich fighting game. LET'S ROCK

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This is my favorite fighting game, and the one that got me into fighting games in general. I played a bit of Mortal Kombat and Soul Calibur when I was a kid, but Guilty Gear is what made me learn what plus-on-block and okizeme mean. Every single facet of this game oozes style and the fights are tight and technical. Characters include a black vampire cyborg samurai, the Secretary of Absolute Defense of the United States and his not-an-alien, a crackhead turned ninja turned president of the Eastern Chipp Kingdom (yes, he is the president of a kingdom), and cute pirate girl who yeets dolphins and hits you with a big fuck-off anchor. Among many others, I'd be here all night describing them all. The lore of the game is insane, and while I do think that +R had (a lot) better character interaction with specific lines for certain matchups and so on, Strive is still fine in that regard, I guess, I keep hoping the devs will patch in some matchup lines but everyone always skips the intros anyway so who cares.

The actual gameplay kicks ass, it's combo heavy but doesn't overdo it like some other fighters (Skullgirls comes to mind) where you have to reliably pull off 37-hit combos to actually execute your gameplan. Some characters are very combo centric but others have a gameplan that solely consists of "walk up and command grab" with everything else you do basically just being setup for your P-Buster. The online servers are pretty shit right now but the devs are reportedly working on making that better. I didn't have a ton of problems when I was playing this game regularly but it was noticeable when you did, you'd drop matches or lag out of the tower and have to rejoin. Playing against your boys on the couch is prime game time, just pick your favorite flavor of busted overpoweredness and pit them against each other.

Mostly I love this game for its style, which specifically is just taking something kind of cool so ridiculously over the top that it turns a bit cringe and then wraps all the way back around into being awesome again. Every menu and loading screen have little bits of flavor text that don't mean anything and you see for .8 seconds before the game loads, it's just there for you to ponder over. Every character looks awesome and feels awesome to play. Literally there are no bad characters, you will find mains of everyone on the roster because this game has a fighter for everyone but every fighter has a unique gimmick. The music is insane, some of it I can pass on but several songs I have become so ridiculously obsessed with that they made it into my daily playlist.

Buy and play this game if you like fighting games, or if you want to learn to like them. If you're a real old school fighting game veteran and you want something that feels more like that, buy Guilty Gear XX Accent Core +R instead, or one of the older Guilty Gear games if you want, there's been quite a few of them. The franchise is about as old as Street FIghter, and in my opinion it has been heavily slept on by the public at large. It's good, especially so if you enjoy the admittedly cheesy but genuinely cool aesthetic.
I have gripes, but they're mostly against the people who play the game.

A fighting game that despite it's somewhat high skill ceiling is actually really easy to get into no matter your experience with 2D fighters, with some of the best in game resources for improvement. Including but not limited to; a godlike training mode, "missions" which are an essence handy tutorials on the game's mechanics, and a public combo sharing mode where you can find, practice, and share different sequences or combos. Not only that, but it has by far the smoothest peer to peer rollback netcode so online practice is very viable. However, the largest crux of this game is also it's online servers, which have... plentiful issues with matchmaking and pairing people together properly. The singleplayer is also extremely lacking, as with most fighting games unfortunately. If you're hoping to get into a 2D fighting game, I cannot recommend Guilty Gear Strive enough as a starting point despite it's flaws.

Actually... this game is kind of bad.

From really bad online service, to terrible balancing.
Not terrible balancing, but bullshit balancing.

Characters are up and down in terms of strengths, similar moves are just straight better with some characters than others. Ramlethal has disjoints, but Testament, a similar-ish character does not. You hit bridget in her yo-yo and she gets hurt, but hit nagoriyuki in his sword and you get hurt.

There are absolute terrible normals as well. Nagoriyuki has a braindead closeslash arguably better than his 6P which should be the anti air, but instead, the close slash is a better anti-air.

The hitboxes are also wacky. Jacko has some absolutely terrible J.normals, getting hit by Nagos Close slash ON THE OTHER SIDE WHEN I WAS CROSSING HIM UP.

The balance and reward also dont make sense. There are characters like Jacko or Zato who are very very hard to play but their reward is lesser than other characters who get their high damage out of seemingly nothing! No setups or anything, just straight damage while other characters have to work for the same reward.

Thats another thing! Because of wonky hitboxes and stuff, and the high damage, the game rewards accidental plays by too much! Someone whiffed (not on purpose) their meaty, the opponent was ready to block, but because of the whiff, the animation looks like he is open, but the opponent presses a button and gets countered by another of the same button into a huge combo.

So characters like Jacko, Zato, Anji maybe and just generally difficult characters do not at all feel rewarding to play. The games balance is way to skewed towards straight fighting. Putting characters like Ram, Nago, Leo etc up there.

Happy chaos is probably the only character who imposes a very difficult strategy if the player can play him right. Although its only difficult in execution, once that is practiced, you get a very frustrating gameplay versus him.

And the game takes too long to try and fine tune the balance. Balance patches are far and few inbetween. Certain characters got certain reworks twice over (Anji) and that just shows how bad the developers assume the gameplay of the characters. With Jacko, nobody uses bomb. They made it easier to combo with but no straight buffs. I do not even think they play any of the difficult characters.

The game also has little defencive mechanics. For a Win-condition strike-throw type fighting game. It sure does love to not let you play. A lot of the mechanics of GG Strive is from past GG games, and I have finally come to see how they do not translate well.

In a slowerpaced fighter such as Strive compared to its previous games, it likes to showcase bullshit moments very obviously. Such as grabs not connecting because just maybe the person was 1 frame off into the blockstun. Or extremely obvious animations that shouldnt hit, yet they do. Resulting in a surprise for both players.

How can a volatile game like this have such hard hitting Rock Paper Scissor situations?
And then go off to reward accidental plays. It just turns out to be frustrating to see that your skill just does not add up to the game. You can see a huge shift in strategy when the opponent who has the flow suddenly looses it because he slightly whiffed a normal, got punished for it and now he is in the corner helplessly.

In defence, since there arent any defencive mechanics essentially, you make 1 single mistake and you are either dead or have to block the ordeal again. Yellow roman cancel and maybe burst are the only defencive mechanics. Instant blocking is a non-mechanic because it is too hard to do and no rewarding to try and do at all. Yet yellow and burst can be baited...

The game is sorely lacking in just straight strategy. Jacko, Goldlewis and the new character Asuka and maybe one or two others are strategy based characters. Yet the reward is very hard to obtain for arbitrary reasons.

Why pick Sin Kiske?!?! Why?! You have Ky and Sol who are better Sin. Straight up. Same moves, but better.

Strive is going to get burried.

The game is fun, but just some qualms I have... The biggest being they had almost a year to listen to people's feedback and yet did not do anything about the lobby system in the game. This is the worst lobby implementation I've ever experience. While playing with some friends in a private lobby, I often can't observe because the queue breaks for some reason, and unlike Street Fighter V you cannot spectate mid-match. The visuals are boring, and it make general match making so much more clunky than it needs to be.

Another lobby related annoyance is that you can't change your character without breaking the queue. The problem with doing that in a lobby is that by leaving the queue you'll be missing out on spectating the next match.

My other big frustration is just how long it takes to get into a game. It takes two minutes after launching to get into the game (where you'll see the message "Communicating with server" flash 60 times). Then you have to go through a similar process when trying to connect to multiplayer.

One of the main system interactions also uses a radial menu, which works for some, but not if you use a keyboard or a button only layout, then it becomes very awkward.

They also released with private lobby codes broken at launch, along with this "follow opponent" option which you see whenever you finish a match. That was just sloppy.

Update 2023-01-23: As of the November 2022 "Bridget" update the game no longer takes 5 minutes to load. Changing review to positive.

Update 2023-05-25: You know what, I can still never get past the horrible loading experience to the game. Changing review to negative.

The short: This review is intended for players looking to buy the game but are still somehow on the fence. Guilty Gear Strive is a fun, accessible fighting game with free form mechanics that make the game complex and intuitive yet simple to learn. Be it a game to sweat your testies off, or to get drunk and play casual with friends, this game has something to please all

The long: I have a few hours in this game now, I've reached Celestial Challenger but havent obtained the rank. I have ample playtime on almost every character, I have a lot of hours in different Fighting Games, so I think there's some value in my opinion.

The Good: Strive is a game that decided to take the Guilty Gear franchise in a different direction than what is "normal" for the series. It's focused on making characters simple, yet still highly differentiated from each other. The new/refurbished Gatling system is the skill floor for the game, learning to chain a normal attack into another normal attack based on the button pressed. It's a simple flow chart of "This button can only be chained into these other buttons" which makes picking up the game exceptionally easy. It still has special move inputs, which can be intimidating to new players, but there aren't anything particularly harsh and the games inbuilt features for learning said inputs and their use cases is extremely well done. The game has what I would consider the gold standard for fighting game tutorials, so as opposed to me rattling on further, just know that this game will hold your hand until you're ready to win your first match

The Bad: Strive does not have skill based matchmaking. It has a ranked system in the form of "floors", which number 1-10, with a secret 11th floor for the exceptionally skilled. You get ranked a floor at the start of the online experience (Which I will get to later) and can challenge any floors above yours, but not floors beneath. This sounds okay on paper, but the problem is that the first 9 floors might as well not exist, as players tend to group around the highest normal floor (10) to try find matches properly. This means the comp experience is pretty much a blind pick. Then the lobby system for non-comp matchmaking is a normal mosh of any player, with no real information on their skill level beyond a profile badge telling you their ranked floor level (which doesnt help if they dont play ranked). This is fine for people like me who don't mind getting bodied for the first few hours while you learn, but I can understand if this is a turn off for some players. There's no good solution for it either, so keep that in mind. I do not deem it a big deal however

The Ugly: The servers for this game right now are in turmoil. They rolled out complete crossplay over all Platforms (Xbox, PS, and PC) which is amazing for the games life cycle. Unfortunately, complications of some kind have occurred and the lobby system is borderline unusable at times. The devs have on multiple occasions left empty messages saying they're looking into it, but only in the last month do I actually believe that they have a plan of attack. It's not the worst, but it is bad. If you have someone to show you what it's like, please look into it yourself. It's not a dealbreaker for me, but it is for a lot of people. This is also not to mention a rampant hacking problem that, while generally only being a problem for people of higher status (Content creators namely), can happen to the regular playerbase. It just locks you out of playing the game you paid for temporarily. It's shit. I have no idea if they can even fix it. The devs barely acknowledge it

Closing note/TL;DR: If you're here to play Jack'O because you saw her pose online, she's a harder character to play, but not as hard as you soldier. Worth
If you're here for a fun fighting game, whether if you're a FG veteran or a beginner, its a good start
please excuse the devs not so bright behavior, they are good devs, just slow sometimes.

If you never played a fighting game and are nervous about picking this up. Don't be! 

Here are some reasons why this should be your first fighting game!

There's over 100 tutorial/challenges that cover basic fighting game fundamentals, and guilty gear strive specific mechanics. 
The game makes sure that they are easy to understand, and has a roadmap of challenges that it teaches you how to complete, gives you the knowledge for, and can get you from absolute beginner to beating your first small town local tournament. 

There's even in an in game player combo creator where you can create your own or test out other player made combos on specific characters so that you don't need to go out of your way to learn combos for other characters if you don't want to. 

 At it's core the training arena gives you so many tools to fine tune whatever it is you're trying to improve on no matter the skill level. 

Online PVP - With rollback netcode as long as you have good internet yourself, matches should feel smooth, and fast paced without the usual stutters all thanks to Rollback Netcode. 

If you're worried about not finding people or majority of players being too pro then don't worry about it. 
I assure you this game is still incredibly popular online and has crossplatform. There's also specific lobbies called the "Tower" where it will restrict expert players from joining rooms meant for beginners only giving you room to practice with others.

If you're want to get good at a fighting game and willing to put in the time. I highly suggest getting this game and completely the tutorial challenges from noob all the way to expert. That knowledge alone will carry you in most of your games, and once your ready you can start learning combos to min max your punishing game.

Pros:
+Amazing Netcode
+Deeper than expected game mechanics
+Relatively well balanced at high levels
+All characters feel unique and interesting
+Great visuals and soundtrack

Mixed (depends on personal tastes):
=Game is dramatically simplified compared to previous games, while some mechanics have been made inexplicably more difficult, such as "Instant Blocking", reversal timing. Seems arbitrary.
=Unless you unlock soundtracks, default OST has lyrics, which may get annoying
=Significantly greater focus on "neutral/footsies" compared to previous titles

Cons:
-Awful lobbies and poorly implemented ranked mode
-Game play may feel extremely limiting for fans of old GG games
-Despite simplification of the game, there is still a steep learning curve that may frustrate new players
-Story mode is a non-playable, 4 hour long, anime that you just watch. No gameplay.
-Arcade mode is boring
-No frame data available in the game; you'll have to use the Wiki/Dustloop

Overall: Highly recommend to fighting game fans, recommend to people interested in learning fighting games, but have a hard time recommending to fans of GGXrd/AC unless you are willing to keep an open mind.

I've had a passive interest in fighting game since I was young but besides playing the first few Mortal Kombat games occasionally never got too deep into them. A few years ago I got into DBFZ and could finally get that enjoyment of learning the fundamentals and what types of characters I liked playing but despite the 3v3 format and fairly long list of characters it began to feel pretty boring with combo routes feeling too familiar and variation lagging behind as I got better.
Even though I had stopped playing DBFZ I still very much enjoyed the idea and looked more into Arcsys and saw that a new game called Guilty Gear Strive was being released and once I saw the unique characters and started getting invested in the lore and especially the music I knew I had to buy the game as soon as I could. This game is probably the best purchase I've made when it comes to games of any kind and I've been so excited to bring in my friends and start learning again.
Honestly worth every dollar including the DLC in my opinion.
There have been a lot of people recently talking about server issues but personally I've not seen any at all, not from the launch and nothing from the past few months either. If you do experience the problems after buying the game though I'd just recommend trying an ethernet connection or, if it's particularly bad, you can always refund (assuming you didn't play for much longer than 2 hours).

tldr; The game is 100% worth it from my experience and if you like the characters, music, or even just the look of the gameplay I'd say give it a shot! If you're coming from DBFZ I can say from experience that this game feels so much more rewarding to play in every way. Good luck, have fun!!

This is literally the fighting game that got me into the FGC, and I'm very glad it did. This game has gorgeous animations, a great soundtrack, and genuinely fun gameplay. I appreciate that a lot of people aren't huge fans of the high damage in this game, but personally I like it. Combos and rounds are generally short, which makes every decision much more important and tense. Plus its easy to rapid fire back to back games in little time. The nice thing about this game as well is that it is, for the most part, fairly well balanced. Even the 'bad' characters, still have notable strengths which can make them viable at almost every level of play. The games netcode is generally very good as well. There are network issues as of right now, which could be annoying. I can't comment on how its affected everyone else, but for me, it hasn't affected me TOO much. The developers have also planned to fix it, and hopefully it will prove to be effective. Overall, if you think the game looks cool and you want to give the game a try, I would highly recommend it. Remember to stay awesome out there!
